The metamorphic grade increases progressively frorn greenshist fàcies in the vr'est and

central parts of the Quadrilátero Ferífero to almancline-amphibolite faoies in the east. This is

demonstrated by the increase in quartz grain size and the presence of diagnostic metamorphic

minerals (Don 1964). LIerz. (1978) identifíecl the isograds of biotite and staurolite separating

three metamorphic zones (chlorite, biotite and staurolite). [Ie also notecl the change from
hematite to specularite under meclium and higher grades of metamorphism. Pires (1995)
reclefinecl these isograds in carbonatic metalutites, which resulted in the cle{inition of three
metamorphic zones: grunerite, cummingtonite-actinolite, ancl tremolite-antophyllite. Moving

east one may observe that the equilibration temperatures of mineral âssemblages in these zones

increase from about 300'C to 600 "C for estimated pressures at 3 to 5 kbar.

The Itabirites of the ltabira Group

Itabirites are oxidized, metamorphosed ancl heterogeneously deformecl banded iron

formations (BIFs) containing discontinuously ilistributed orebo<ìies, which vary in scale from
just a few centimeters to hundrecls of meters. Multipte processes have obliteraled partially or

totally the mineralogy, texture and structure of the original secliments, making it difficult to
identify primary characteristics, especially in the high-strain domain. In the lo.,,v strain domâirì,

the itabirites have preserved several sedimentary and diagenetic features snch as meso and

microbanding pocls formed by clifferential compaction and pisolites (Rosiere ct al. 2001).
Banding is the main intemal feature of the itabirites. Tight ancl isoclinal folds commonly
showing a crenulation cleavage and pinch-ancl-swell structures are locally observed. Shear zones

ate restrictecl to a few places and founcl parallel to banding or truncating it. Kink-bands are very



46

common in the weatherecl itabirites and have been interpretecl by Ribeiro ,and Zavaglta (1998) as

collapse structures.

Quartz itabirite is the major type of itabirite in the Quaclrilátero Ferrífero. In this rock

type the original chert or jasper bands l'rave been recrystallizecl into granular quartz, and iron ìs

present as hematite, magnetite or martite. Dolomitic itabirite is a dolomitized BIF consisting of

alterna[ing recl carbonate and black iron oxide bands, eacl, being between I mm and 50 crn thick.

Arnphibolitic itabirite consists of bancls of many types of amphiboles (grunerite, tremolite,
actinolite, cummingtonite ancl/or anthophilite) alternating with bancls of iron oxicles (Rosière et

al. 1993).

llematite is the major iron oxicle in dìe itabirites, occuring in clifferent forms: martite

(pseuclomorphs of hematitc af'ter magne tite), granular hematite and specularite (Don 1964, 1965;

Rosière 1981, 1983, 2000). Magnetite appears subordinately as the Fe2r. deficient variety

kenomagnetite (metastable magnetic phases which are somewhere between magnetite and

maghemite in composition), and as relicts in martite ancl hematite aggregates. Both iron oxicles

were developecl at various stages during the complex evolution of the Quadrilátero Ferrífero, as

shown by Rosière (,l981, 1983) and Rosière et al, (2001). Magnetite is the oldest recognizable

iron oxide. Mostly it appears to have been totally or partially martitized. Granular hematite
results from the progressive martitization, inversion and recrystallization of magnetite.
Specularite results from recrystallization of kenomagnetite, martite or hernatite in high-strain

domains or shear zones (Rosière et al. 2001). Otherwise it occurs in extensional sites associated

with quartz or carbonates (Lagoeiro 1998). Goethite occurs close to the surface, or along fracture

planes, locally associated with gibbsite and kaolinite.

Quartz is the main gangue mineral of itabirites. The next most common are dolomite ancl

amphiboles, which are present either as intelcalated bands ot disseminations. Chlorite, talc,
apatite and various silicate minerals occur in very smâll quantities except in the high
metamorphic-grade zones, where they can be common (Dorr 19'13). Wavelite
(A13(PO4)r(OfÐj.sHzO) is restricted to a few cleposits in the Quaclrilhtero Fcrrífero.

The lron Ores of the ltabira Group

Iton ores have been formed thronghout the Quadrilátero Ferrífero by the enrichment of

itabirites- They are generally classifiecl, accorcling to tho iron content, into high-grade ancl low-

gracle ores. Hrgh-grade oles have Fe contents higher than 64%o, wilh very low contents of the



47

contaminants SiOz, AlzO:¡, CaO, MgO etc. The Fe contents of the low-gracle ores vâry ftom 32o/o

to 64%, with different amounts of contaminants.

The iron oxide tnineralogy of ores is the same as that of the itabirites. Gangue minerals

are rarely present in the high-glade ore but, where found, consist of relicts of quartz, clolomite,

chloritc, amphibole ancl talc. Low-grade ores contain the same gangue minerals found ili the
protore. These vary in quantity accorcling to tlie degroe of iron enrichment-

The iron ores cân be subcìivided iuto hard ancl soft types. liarcl ores can be bancled,

massive, lineated, schistose ancl seconclalily brecciatccl. Soft ores can be foliatecl, lineatecl or free

ofany stlucture (blue dust ore) (Rosière ct al. 1993; Rosiòre 2000).

Genetic Models For Thc lron Ores

Although largely discussed in the intcmational literatrro, the genesis of the high-gracle

iron ore deposits hostecl within BIFs remains unclear. Different genetic models have been
proposed worldwide to explain the iron enrichment of the BIFs. Morris (2002) identified eleven

iron ole gerretic moclels and groupecl them in three classes: syngenetic, supergene and hypogene.

Based on field investigations and literature surveys, Beukes et al. (2002) recognized three
genetic models of high-grade iron ore deposits: ancient supergener hydrothermal ancl supergene-

modifi eil hydrothermal deposits.

The supergene models explain the iron enrichment as a tesult of leaching of the gangue

minerals by supergene fluids. (e.g. Dor 1964, Monis 1985). These models are generally
accepted as an explanation for the high-grade iton ores associated with present or past erosion

surfaces. Hypogene models are more complex. They propose the action of hydrothermal fluids

substituting tlre gangue minerals for iron oxides o¡ iron carbonates (e.g. Dorr 1965, Gruner 1937,

Powell et ù1. 1999, Morey 1999). Taylor et al. (2001) recently proposed a composite model to

explain the genesis of the high-grade iron ore of the llamersley Province. For a general
understanding concerning the high-grade iron ores genesis see Beukes et al. (2002) ancl Molris

(2002). For additional information see Lascelles (2002), Morcy (1999), Monis (1987), Powell et

al. (1999), Taylor et al. (2001), Van Schalkwyk and Beukes (1986), and references thelein.

The genesis of tho iron ores within the Cauê Formation in the Quadrilátero Fenífero has

been the subject of clebate since the beginning of the 20th century, ancl contimres to be the focus

of stuclies by several researchers (e.g. Harder and Chamberlin l9l5; Guild 1953; Park 1959;
Dorr 1964, 1965; Rarnanaidou 1989; Ramanai<lou et al. 1996; Rosière and Rios 2003). Soft ores

have been expleritred as resiclual concentrations of iron oxicles clue to leaching of contaminatìts



48

during supergene processes (Dorr 1964; Eichler 1968; Melfi et al. 1976; Viel et al. 1987;
Ramanaidou 1989; Ramanaidou et al. 1996). They have also been viewecl as a consequence of

incomplete metasomatism ofthe BIF followed by weathering, as suggested by Don (1965). I{ard

ores have been generally considered to result from the I'eplacement or leaching of gangue

minerals (Dort 1965). The precisc timing ofore formation is also a source of controversy. Dor
(1965), for instance, postulated both syn-metamorphic and syn-deformational mineralization.

But there remains clobate ovø the importance of these events (Rosiòre 1981, Rosière aucl Rios

2003).

THE ÁGUAS CLARAS OREBODY

General Description

Mining at Águas Claras commencecl in 1973 antl by 2002 ca.288 Mt of high-grade iron ore hacl

been mined. The highest annual output was in 1992 when 14 Mt of iron ore \¡r'el'e minecl. The

Águas Claras mine was closecl in 2002 with an annual production of 1.2 Mt. About 88 Mt of
high-grade iron orc rcmains, but economic ancl environmental restrictions indicate that mining

cannot continue. The ore was mined by open-pit methods and treated at a local ore-clressing

plant. This resulted in three products: lump ore (13%: 31.5- 6.30 mm), sinter feed (.43%: 6.30 -
0.15 mrn) and pellet leed (32o/o:0.15 mrn - 0.038 mrn), with l2%o of tailings. Table 2 presents
the size distribution of the particles ancl the chemical composition of these proclucts over recent

yeafs.

Structure and Stratigraphy ofthe Mine Area

The Águas Claras iron mine is locatecl on the northern eclge of the Sena clo Curml, in a
northeast-southwest trending homocline with bedcling dipping steeply to the southeast (Fig. 2a).

The Cataça, Itabira and Piracicaba Groups of the Minas Supergroup crop out along most of the

extension of tlie Seüa clo Curral in an inverted sequeuce without repetilion (Chemale et al.

1994). Tlte inverted stratigraphic seqnence, as well as locally preserved seclimentary structures,

led Pomerene (1964), Dom (1969), Pires (1979) and Alkmim ancl Marshak (1998) to propose that

the homocliue represents a remnant of the overturned ümb of a northwest-vergent anticline. At

its northern segment, the Serua clo Curral is highly strained ancl lefllaterally rotated flom its

original position. Wide shear zones occur at the contact of the Minas Supergroup with the Rio

das Vellras Supergtoup (Chemale et al. 1994). In the vicinity of the mine bedding is transposed



49

by axial plane schistosity and locally developed rnylonitic foliations, gcnerally striking N45"E,

with dips ranging fi'om 30' [o 70' to the southeast.

The beginning of thc dolomitic itabirite seqr.rence is marked by the appearance of

At the Águas Claras mine, clolomitic itabirite is much more common than quartz itabirite.

The dolomitic itabirite: mesoscopic features, petrogrâphy and chemistry

Banding is the most striking structure of the dolomitic itabirite. It occurs as mesobanding and

microban<ling of Trendall (1973). Thc characteristic centimeter-scale mesobancling of
carbonate/oxide layers produces the reddish/dark rock banding (Fig. 5b). Mesobands rarige in

thickness from 0,1 cm to 50 cm, with an average thickness of approximately I cm, At the
lowermost part of the clolomitic layer, in the contact with the phyllite, the carbonate mesobancls

are thicker (10-50 cm) than the oxide mesobands (0.5 -3 cm). The thickness of the carbonate

mesobands decreases upwarcls, so that in the mid section of the sequence both mesobaucls
clisplay approxirnately the same thickness varying florn less thau I mrn to 0.6 crn. At the top of



the sequence, the thickness of the carbonate mesobands increases again in relation to the oxide

mesobands, reaching l5-50 cm.

Dolomite lens and veins of variable thickness - from a few millimeters to - 20 cm - are
inegularly distributed in the dolomitic itabirite, crosscutting or parallel to the bedding. Some of
these dolomite lens and veins have been deformed together with the dolomitic itabirite (Fig. 5c).

Especially at the base of the sequence, but also in some narrow centimeter thick zones towards

the top, the dolomitic itabirite is brecciated, with the bands of carbonate and iron oxides
cemented by dolomite.

The red carbonate mesobands of dolomitic itabirite consist of very fine grained spary

dolomite and hematite with grain size varying from 5 - 30 ¡rm (at an average of 12 pm, Fig. 6a-

b). The volume of hematite within the carbonate mesobands is highly variable (5% to 50% from

band to band). Locally, the dolomite occurs together with hematite in extensional sites, forming

geodes (Fig. 5f). Hematite occurs mainly as martite, forming euhedral crystals in masses of
elongated and lobate shapes (Fig. 6b). It also occurs as euhedral to subhedral crystals in the
martite aggregates, and as isolated crystals occupying the interstices or included in grains of
dolomite. Platy hematite (specularite) occurs in shear planes, surrounding crystals of martite or

granular hematite (Fig. 6c).

Randomly oriented red-brown microcrystals of hematite (<I pm) are found in dolomite crystals
in the carbonate mesobands (Figs. 6d and 7a), resulting in the characteristic deep red color of
these mesobands. Small fluid inclusions (<8 pm) are abundant in dolomite. These are cunently

53



54

undel investigation, Preliminary data reveal two phase fluicl inclusions made up of gas and
liquid, without salt crystals.

The iron oxide mesobands contain hematite (>90%), interstitial carbonates and pores.

The average homatite grain size is siurilal to that of the dolomite mesobancls (- 12 pm) varyìng
from 5 - 20 pm- Flematite occurs maìnly in the form of martite, alìd locally as specularite- Relicts

of kenomagnetite are observecl in the nuclei of some martite crystals, especially in the coarser

mesobands of iron oxitlcs. Marlite and granular hematite crystals can be founcl fused together

forming a clense net\¡r'otk.

Accessoty minerals are also present in the mesobands. Talc occurs inter.grown with
dolomite and in thin veins with chlorite. Apatito can be found in layers (<I mm) as isolated
euheclral crystals (4 - l0 pm) and intergrown with or inclucled in hematite and dolomite crystals
(Fig. 6e). Chlorite occurs along veins ancl shear planes. An iron ancl nickel oxicle (possibly

trevorite) was identified in one sample forming fine crystals intergrown with hematite in the iron

oxide band (Fig. 61). Isolatecl crystals of titanite were also identified irr one sample of dolomitic

itabirite.

ln order to assess the bulk cornposition of the dolomitic itabirite, 33 samples were taken

from the bottom to the top of the stratigraphic sequence and analyzed for major elements in the

MBR laboratory. Because of the extreme birnodal composition of the dolomitic itabirite, each
sample (-100 kg) consisted of several band couplets of alternating iron- and carbonate,r.ich
layers. The results ate shown in Table 3. These reveal that the bulk composition is dominatecl by

Fe2O3, CaO and MgO which, together with LOI, make up more than 97yo of the rock.

The high-grade Fe ore at the Águas Claras Mine

Unlike other mines in the Quaclrilátero Ferrífero, the Águas Claras mine contains only
high-grade ores. These consist of two distinct, main types: soft an<l hard ore. 'I'he sofl ore
rep[esents 85% of the overall resource, whefeas the hard ore lepresents only 15o/o. The orebody

was a concordant, 2,500 m long, roughly tabular-shaped lens with a maximum thickness of 300

m, formed essentially by soft ores (Fig. ab). The depth of the ore is variable, extencling to over

400 tn below the sutface at the center of the pit bottom and then grading into the parental fresh

dolomitic itabirite deeper down (Fig. 4a). The haril ores generally occut within the soft ores as

minor lens. 'fhese are concotdant to the bedding, although locally they rnay be discorclant ancl

associated with shear zones. The main hard ole occurrences are concentratecl to the wes[ of the

mine, close to the top ofthe sequence. llere they are in contact with qtnrlz itabilite forrning lens

of up to 200 m length along the strike, with thicknesses varying from 5 - 60 r¡ (Fig. 4b). Small
concordant lens of hard ore measuring from a few centimeters to nearly a meter thick occur
within the clolomitic itabirite at the east sicle of the pit. These lens consist of massive hard ore

formed by almost pure hematite.

The soft ore is characteristically porous ancl very friable. It disaggregates during tlic
mining operations and generates a low lump yield. It usually preserves the structure of the
itabilite, particularly the meso and microbancling (Fìg.5g), and sometimes exhibits kink-bands

not presenl in the protore.

The harcl ore is dense, compact and generates a high lLrmp yield. Three main subtypes of
harcl ore are found at the Águas Claras mine: massive, banded and schistose (Fig. 5h). Massive

hard o¡e has a very low porosity, does not exhibit any kind of structure and commonly shows

signs of conchoidal fracture. Banded hard ore varies in porosity and is characterized by
conspicuous banding- This is the typical hartl ote founcl as small tens witliin the soft ore.
Schistose harcl ore genelally has low porosity, does not preserve the original structures and

exhibits a conspicuous cataclastic foliation. 'Ihis type of hard ore is associated with shear zones

which are mainly found on the north wall of the pit. The larger bodies of harcl ore are usually

intensely fiactured, with thin films ofgoethite and kaolinite along the fracture planes (Fig. 5h5).

The iron oxides whích form the soft aud hard ores are the same as those observed in the
dolomitic itabitite: hematite as martite, granular hematìte ancl specularite with subordinatecl
remnant kenomagnetite cores pteserued in some martite grains. These minerals typically
preserve the original size ancÌ shapes present in the protol'e. Gangue minerals are rarely found in

the masses of soft orc, ancl consist of dolomite, chlorite, talc and apatite. They occru rnainly at



58

the contact zone with the protore, In this zone, the soft ore contains remnants of dolornite and a

brownish residue generated from the rlissolution of dolomite (Fig. 7b). Microcrystals of hematite

are present, as well as apatite, chlorite and talc. 'fhe latter is observed as isolated platelets or as

millimeter-sized aggregates. A few meters away from the contact zone, most of the gangue
minerals disappear. h the harcl ores interbeclcled with fresh dolomitic itabirite, the dolomite
occurs as an accessory mineral. Manganese-oxides (mainly litioforite) occur in narrow zones at

tlÌc contact witli the protore. Goethite occuls frlling poles, voids ancl fractures in soft and l.rard

otes close to the lancl sruface.

Tlie soft ore consists of alternâte microbands of lower ancl higher porosity, containing marlite

and hematite (Fig. 8a), wrth intergranular porosity visually estimated at 35-45 percent (Fig. 8b).

Thin bancls of specularite occur parallel to or cross-cutting thc banding. The hard ores have a

similar mineralogical compositiou regarclless of their physical oha¡acteristics. They consist of a

dense network of martite ancì hematite with a varying ploportion of pores (Fig. 8c-d).
Kenomagnetite is regularly observed in the nuclei of martite crystals especially in the largel lens

of harcl ores.

The massive hard ote consists of weakly orientecl aggregates of martitc (with relicts of

kenomagnetite) ancl hematite with a granoblastic texture and an avelage grain size ranging from

5- l5 ¡Lm. A visual estimation suggests that intergranular porosity is around 5- l0 percent. Banclecl

liatd ores exhibit a prirnary banding formecl by the alternation of rnicrobands where hematite is

predominant (low porosity) with microbands where maltite is predominant (high porosiLy), The

global intergranular porosity of the banded harcl ores is extremely variable (fiom 10% to 30%).

Samples collected from thin lens of the banded ore present within the soft ores are more porous

than those collected from larget lens on the west sicle of the mine. Schistose hard oles are
essentially formed of speoularite, which is strongly oriented, ancl exhibits a low intergranular

porosity.

Table 4 shows statistics regarding ths majol eletneut cornposition of about 5,300 samples ofrun-

of-mine iron ore collected by MBR since 1971. This geochemistry database was usecl by the

company to estimate the quality of the products. lt illustrates the size distribution of the pârticles,

and the chemical composition of the 288 Mt of iron ore which has been mined. The samples

were screened into 3 size fractions (50.00 - 6.30 mm, 6.30 - 0.15 mm and <0.15 mm), and

analyzed together with the bulk samples. No bulk sample containecl less than 64% Fe1, which

was the arbitrary limit set between the high-grade iron ore ancl the itabilite. Lower grades of Fe

occur in the <0.15 mm size fraction, where impurities are concentrated. SiOz, Al2O3, Mn and P

contents are higher than those observed in the coarser sized fractions. The chemistry of the hard

anrl soft ores is very similar. The hard ore has higher P ancl AlzO: contents while the soft orc is

higher in Mn, CaO, MgO and TiOz.

A representative clrill core (D[I-17185), which cuts all the sofÌ ore from the bottom of the Cauê

Formatiorì going through the fresh dolomitic itabirite, is shown in Figure 9. The coarse fiaction

is scatce in the soft ore especially when close to the contact with the canga and the fresh

dolomitic itabirite. The contaminants are concentrated in the fines (<0.15 mm), clue to their

small size crystals. Their SiO2 and Al2Or contents arc due to talc anrì chlorite, P to apatite and

Mn to Mn oxicles.

THE PICO OREBODY

General Description

Procluotion ofiron ore at Pico has been carriecl out from 1968. During this periocl, 120 Mt

of iron ore wele mined. The Pico mine, together with the Galinheiro and Sapecado mines, form

the Pico Complex and are currently responsible fì¡r 50% of MBR's production. About l93 Mt of
high-gracle ores remains at the Pico mine. The ore is mined through open-pit methods and is

treated at local ore dressing plants which have an annual capacity of l2 Mt. Four proclucts are

fonnd in the major plant: the lump ore (31 .5 - 12.0 mm), the "hematitinha" (12.0 - 6.30 rnm), the

sinter feed (<6.30 - 0.15 mm) and the pellet feed (<0.15 - 38 pm). flistor.rcally thesc have
represented 16%, 1%,32Yo ancl26%o of the procluotion respectively, wü\ lgyo tailings. Table 2
shows the percentage and ohemical composition ofeach ofthese proclucts in recent years.

Structure and stratigraphy of the mine area

The Pico iron mine is locatecl on the eastern inve¡ted limb of the Moeda Syncline, which

is one of the major stl'uctures of the Quadrilátero Fenífero (Fig. t ). In contrast \¡r'ith the Ser¡a do

Cttrral, where the Águas Claras mine is located, the Moeda Syncline is a lelatively less strained

domain. Bedding and other seciimentary structures are well prcserued. Ductile shear zones occur

locally trr.rncating or parallel to the bedcling of the Minas Supergroup strata (Chernale et al.
t9e4).

The major geological unìts plesent at the mine are itabirites and ilon ores of the Cauê

Formation, clastic metasedimentary rocks of the Moeila and Batatal F'ormations ancl
predomrnantly chemical metasedimentary rocks of the Gandarela Formation (Fig. l0). The rocks

of these units are oriented along a general stlike N30"-35'E, clipping 45"-90' to SE or NW. The
BIFs have been folded and dips vary fiom 20" to 85", either to the SE 01. to [he NW.
Nevertheless, the quartzitos of the Moeda Folmation thaI crop out continuously along the eastelll

part of the mine (Fig. 2b) show a very consistent sub,vertical dip and, in general, weakly
developecl foliation.

The quartzites exhibit abtupt contacts with the phyllites of the Batatal Formation. There

ate clearly two types of phyllites. The first, in contact with the quar.tzite, is grey, laminated and

rich in sericite. The second, ât the top of the sequence, close to the quartz itabirite, is btown,

weakly laminated and highly porous. Lens of meta-chert, from several meters to 70 meters long

ancl from 5 to 20 meters wicle, occur within this second type of phyllite. The fielcl r.elations
suggest a hansition similâr to that observecl at Águas Claras, frorn quartzite to sericitic phyllite

62



OJ

and clolomitic phytlite, but no frosli samples are available to confìrm this interpretation. The

corrtact between th€ Batatâl and Cauô Formations is abrupt ancl defined by a thin layer of

hernatitic phyllite whioh varies in thickness frorn 2 - 5 m and occurs between the phyllite and

iron formations.

Thc main iron formation at the Pico rnine is the quartz itabirite, whioh is the protore of
the soft high- and low-gracle ores. Amphibolitic itabirite occurs locally in the northcm part of the

mine.

The Ganclarela Formation outcrops at the west wall of the pit. It consists of clolomitio
phyllite and tlceply weathered dolomite with a gradual contact with the itabirites. It is rnarked by

manganese-rich layers interlayered within the itabirites. Fresh samples of the dolomites from

drill oores consisl essentially of spany dolomite crystals varying from 7 - 40 pur (average of l5

pm) with âccessory talc and hematite.

A dyke of metamafic rock clatecl at 861 Ma (U,Pb conoorclia age in baddeleyite, Teixeira

2002, personal communication) with an average thickness of 40 m cuts all lithologies of the

Minas Supergroup in the mine a¡ea,

Gravels and boulclers of itabirite and hald ore cemented by clay, qlartz ancl hematite

occur at the base of small basins iruegularly clistributecl along the strike of the itabirite sequence

at the Pico Mine. These basins are similar to those described in the region by Wallace (1965) ancl

dated by Lima and Cheboldaeff (1981) as Paleocene to Eocene.

Itabirites at the Pico Mine

As elsewhere in the Quadrilátero Ferrífero, banding is the most typical mesoscopic
structure of itabirites at the Pico mine. The thickness of tl,e mesobancls varies from a few
milimeters to 2 cm (0.7 cm in average). The clark oxicle bands of the quartz itabirite consist of
martite and granular hematite with varying amounts of quartz (Figs. I la, l2a). Euhedral martite

orystals are typically porous ancl form irregularly shaped aggregates. They generally contain

relicts of kenomagnetite in the nuclei (Fig. l2b), especially in the coarser dar-k bancls. Subhedral

to euhedral hematite crystals suround the crystals and aggregates of mattite.

The light bands consist of quartz with variable amounts of interstitial granular hematite

and/or martite (Fig. l2c). Locally, the fresh quartz itabirite may show a higher. content of il.oll

oxides within lhe quàrtz bancls. Quartz grain size ranges from l0 to 120 pm (50 pm in average)

while hematite grain size varies from 6 to 80 pm (35 ¡"rm in average). Quartz grains are
commonly equidimensional ancl granoblastic-polygonal with equiangular triple points that
suggest static recrystallisation. Most grains are slightly stl'ained, showing wavy extinction. Tiny

crystals of red hematite (3 - l0 pm) occur commonly as inclusions in the qr.rartz crystals.

Major differences between the Aguas Claras and Pico mines

Both the Águas Claras and Pico mines are hostecl within the Paleoproteroic itabirites of

the Cauê Formation. Although located in the \¡r'estem and less cleformecl side of the Quadrilátero

Ferrífero, the two mines exhibit clifferent patterns of deformation. At the Águas Claras mine a

penetrative schistosity and a crenulation have developed as a consequence of events that folcled

and thrusted the rocks of the Minâs Supergroup. In the Pico mine the deformation was less

1.30 0.6f3 4.3fì 018



71

intense. The structures observed reflect shallow depths ancl low temperâtures. Pervasive
schistosity and crenulation \¡r'erc not cleveloped.

The main lithological cli.lference between the deposits is the presence of clolomitic
itabirite in Águas Claras and amphibolitic itabirite in Pico. The genesis of the clolomitic ancl

amphibolic itabirites retnains a source of controversy and cliscussion (Dorr 1965, Veríssimo et al.

2002, Rosière and Rios 2003). For some authors (Veríssimo 1999, Veríssimo et a|.2002), they

represent a sec{imentary facies variation of the Minas sedimcnts. For others (Beukes et al. 2002),

the dolomitic itabirite results from the diagenetic replacement ofchert by calbonate.

The gradual âppearance of quartz within the dolomite bancls, the absence of evidence

indicating replacement of one mineral by the other and the altetnating banding of quartz bands,

dolomite bands and iron oxide bands (Fig. 5e) characterize a grâdual contact between clolomitic

and quartz itabirites at the Águas Claras mine ancl coulcl reprosent a seclimentary facies vatiation.

The same mineral assemblage of quartz-clolomite-iron oxicles founci in a very low-gra<le
metamorphic iron-formation of the Sokoman Iron Formation in Canadá was described by Klein

alìd Fink (197 6) as a sedímentary hematite-carbonate facies of the BIF. This could also be the

case in Águas Claras.

At the Pico mine, lens of amphibolitic itabirite occur interlayered with quartz itabirite.

The same occurs at the Alegria mine, in the eastern region of the Quadrilátero Ferrífero
(Veríssimo 1999, Veríssimo et al. 2002). Basecl on field relations, petrology ancl geochemistry

ilata, they have interpreted the amphibolitic itabirite and the quartz itabirite as representatives of

the silicate facies and cllert facies respectively. The difficulty in applying the concept of
sedimentary facies to iron formations (James 1974) of the Quadrilátero Fetrífero is clue to the

fact that lhe mineral assemblage presently observed may not reflcct the original mineralogical

composition of the sediments of the Minas basin, which have undergone a complex evolution.

No primary minerals are preserved, tlìe textures of the rocks are typically metamorphic and the

new mineral assemblage is strongly oxidized.

Olherwise there is no fielcl eviclence of a regional clesilicification ancl carbonatization of
the quartz itabirite as suggestecl by Beukes et al. (2002). Dolomitic itabirite and clolornite of the

Cauê Formation occur along tens of kilometers of the Serra do Cunal presenting gradual
contacts. The gradual contact between the Cauê and Gandarela Formations brings an additional

and important difficulty for the idea of carbonatization of the quartz itabirite. The rocks of the

Ganclarela Formation are typically shallow-water carbonate sediments which comprise clolomites

ancl marbles with stromatolitic stÍucturcs (Don 1965, Babinsky et al. 1995). At the base, the



72

Gandarela Formation is composed of dolomitic itabirite and the marble facies is subordinate or

absent. Qualtz itabirite occurs interlayered with dolomitic itabirite, dolomite and marbles (Dorr

1965). These relations suggest again sedimentary facies variation. At the Águas Claras mine the

transition from the Cauê Formation to the Gandal'cla Fomation is marked by the gradual
disappearance of iron oxides in the itabirite. If the dolomitic itabirite were a product of
clesilicification ànd carbonattzàtion of the quarlz itabirite, why would it be in gradual contact
with typical marine carbonate of thc Gandarela Forrn¿tion? And what woulcl be the origin of
carbonates, ifthere is no carbonate rocks underlying the Cauô Formation?

Receirt exploration works coûductcd by MBR along the eastern limb of the Moeda
Syncline have shown that the interlayering of amphibolitic itabirite and quartz itabirite and, on a

small scale, dolomitic itabirite and dolomite, is very frequent. The absence of additional clata on

fluid inclusions, trace and isotope geochemistry etc. preclucìes a final conclusion on this subjcct.

The protore of the iron ores in the Águas Claras mine was dolomitic itabirite, whereas in the
Pico mine it is the quartz itabirite. This significant difference plays an important role with regarcl

to the type of o¡e in each mine. In the Águas Claras mine thete are only high-gracle iron or.es.

Soft ores predominate and exhibit shaq, contacts with the protore. They consist of almost purc

hematite with no relicts of carbonate. The weathering of the quartz itabirite generated only small

bodies of iron-rjch itabirite and Ieft the main part of it unaltered. At the Pico mine the soft high-
gracle iton ore is associated with iron-rich ancl quartz itabirites of various clegrees of alteration.

The transitlon from the sofi high-graile ore to the jron-rich itabirite, and from this to the quartz

ltabirite, is typically gradational especially in the soft ore close to the land surface. In thís ore,

relicts of quartz are common.

The irou oxide mineralogy of the ores in the Águas Claras ancf Pico mines is similar in

grain size, crystal shape and the types of minerals found - basically martite and granular/tabular

hematite. Specularite is a minor component and is restrioted to sheal zones in the Pico rrine. lt
occurs more extensively in the Águas Claras mine due to a higher degree of clefor.mation.
Although the high-grade ores in both mines have very low contents ofgangue rninerals, they are

quite diffelent ñ'om each other. In the Águas Claras mine, clolomite is the main gangue miner.al,

which is found as relict in contact regions with the protore, or as an accessory mineral in the

unweathered hard ores. In thc Pico mine, quartz is the main gangue mineral, present as a relict in

soft and hard high-grade ores, as an accessory mineral in unweathered harcl high-grade ores and

as an important constituent ofthe iron-rich itabirite,



-7.)

The different protores in the Águas Claras and Pico mines irnply that the chemistry of the

ores is a little clifferent. In general, the high-grade ores of the Águas Claras minc havc higher Fe,

Mn, CaO and MgO conterìts than tlìose of llìe Pico mines ('labtes 5 and ó). lligh-gracle ores fiorn

the Pico mine exhibit higher contents of SiOz and cspecially AlzOr, both of which are
particularly scarce in Águas Claras. The chemical clifferences between Águas Claras ancl Pico

high-grade ores are well illustrated in the size fiaction <0.15 mm of the soft hematite ores. 'fhe

Mn, Ca and Mg contents of the Águas Claras mine are respectively 3.6, 7-l antl 4.7 times higher

than those of the Pico mine. In atldition, the SiOz antl Al2O3 contents of the same size iuterval in

the Pico mine are respectively 2.5 and 1.6 higher than those of the Ágr.ras Claras mine. Table 7

summarizes the rnajor differences between the mines.

Considcrations about the iron ore genesis

I-lypotheses on the genesis of the Quadrilátero Ferrífero iron ores have long been

discussecl in the literature, but leseachers are still fa1 from reaching a consensus on this matter

(Flarcler and Chamberlin 1915, Guilrl 1953, Park 1959, Dou 1964 and 1965, Rosière 1983, Pires

2002, Rosiére and Rios 2003). The oomplex scenario where by the Minas Supergroup rocks

evolved, with a multitude of processes generating several sub-types of harcl ancl soft-ores, ancl

the lack of infonnatìon concerning those processes rnake it clif{icult to build a genetic model.

The two major types of iron oros at tlìe Águas Claras and Pico mines - hard and soft ores

- have cleally different genesis: hard ore is hypogene whe¡eas soft ore is supergene. In boih
mines, hard high-grade ore is found interbedded ot cutting unweathered itabirites, ivhich
inclicates its hypogene origin. The timing of its origin is unknown. I-Iowever, a general inclication

74

can be given. lrr the Pico mine a 861 Ma metamafic rþke cuts thin lens of tlie hard ore. Ou the

other hancì, there is no evitlence of contact metamorphism in the soft ores. This indicates that the

harcl ore is okler than 861 Ma and that the soft olc is younger.

Recent papers concerning the genesis of the harcl ores in the Quadrilátero Fenífero (Pires

et al. 2002, Rosière ancl Rios 2003) review old genetic models based on the metamorphic-

metasomatic replacement of the gar,gue rninerals by hematite during metamorphism and
clef'ormation (Dorr and Barbosa 1963, Dorr 1965). Flychothennal processesJ genemlly accepted

by Brazilian geologists, are probably responsible for the genesis of the harcl ores, but many

questions remain rcgarding the timing of those processes, frequcncy, origin, composilion and

temperature of the fluicls. Several sub-types of hard high-gracle ores occut at the Águas Claras

and Pico mines (ancl throughout the Quadrilátero Ferrífero). Rosiére and Rios (2003) interpret

the massive harcl ore as the frrst generation of the high-grade ore, which occnrrcd during a fìrst

hydrothermal event (low-salinity fluids) at temperahues lower than 150'C. This event would be

related to the late diagenesis of the Minas sequonce. Pires (2002) argues that this same massive

ore ancl the brecciated hard ore were formed later during metamorphism and cleformation of the

soquence uncle¡ brittle regime. Thin bedclecl, banded, micaceous and schistose hard ores were

created during the same rnetamorphic event in a previous synkinematic, acicl and oxidant
metasornatism. under ducti le regime.

The genesis of the soft high-grade ores and iron-¡ich itabirites was studied by sevelal

ar.rthors (Dorr 1964; Eichler 1968; Melfi et al. 1976; Viel et al. 1987; Ramanaidou 1989;

Ramanaidou et al. 1996). According to them, fìeld relations ancl petrographic observations

clearly demonstrate that these ores are the result of the resiclnal concentration of the iron oxicles

clue to the leaching of associated gangue minerals by supergene fluids. The weathering process

was enhanced by the well-clefined bedcling at high angles in lhe itabirites at the Águas Claras ancl

Pico mines. This allowed deep penetratior, of weathering fluids, which are abundant in humicl,

tropical climates. This process was also favorecl by the appropriate physiographic environmen[

where the itablrites occur along high ridges wifh adjacent steep slopes, etrhancing the circulation

of grouncl water (Dorr 1964).

A supergene origin seems very clear, especially for the soft ore antl the iron-rich itabirite

that occur close to the lancl surface, where it is possible to document the gradual transition from

the fresh itabirite to the iron-rich itabirite and then to the soft ore. It is not so clear in the lower

benches of the mine where the soft high-grade ore is in sharp contact with the soft itabirite of



75

low ilon content. lD this case one could suppose a previous iron enrichment of the itabiritic

protore, but there is no cvidence of this.

Soft higlr-grade ores cropping out close to the land surface at the Pico mirre have the

same physical and chemical characteristics as those present at deeper depths, except where they

arc in contact with lhe canga. In this case, they show higher Al2O3 and P contents and higher

LOI.

The soft ores of tlie Pico mine preselrt Fe contents similar to those of the Águas Claras

rnine. This fact led to interesting discussions on why two different protores generate similar soft

ores. For Viel et al. (1987) the composition of the prirnitive itabirite would control the type of

soft ore genelated. For irstance, dolomitic itabirite would generate soft high-grade ore whcrcas

quartz itabirite would generate iron-rich itabirite. This idea could explain the soft ores of the

Águas Claras mine, but not those of the Pico mûre. Unweathered quartz itabirite cropping out

close to the soft ofes at thc Pico mine do not contain carbonate. Therefore, though the original

composition of the itabirite lepresents a very important factor iu the genesis of the soft ore, it is

nol the only factor. The presence offavorable structules rnust also be considered.

Faults and fractures, for instance, facilitate the access of weathering fluids to the
unweathered rock. A very good exarnple of structural control carr be found at the Pico mine,

where the soft ore occurs only on the south side of the metamafic dyke (Fig. l0). The dyke acted

as a barrier for the fluids coming from tlie south and favoled an iuteusive leacliing ofthe gangue

minerals close to its colltact.

At thc Águas Claras mine it is reasonable to oonsider that, though both dolornitic ancl
quartz itabirite are present as protores, the rnajority of soft ores are derived from the carbonatic

lock due to its higher susceptibility to be leached. The absence of favorable slructural conû'ol

preseffed the qvartz itabirite. This was not the case at the Pico rnine, where favorable shuctural

controls facilitatecl the weathe|ing of the quartz itabirite and the formatiorr of high-grade soft

ores.

Chemically, the weatheling pr¡cess is oharacterized by a liigh concentration of Al2O3 and

P in the canga ancl in the iron ores that are in contact with it. The confents ofthese contarninants

decrease quickly at glcatcr clepths (Fig. 9), whele the soft- ol'es consist of almost pure hematite

witl.r more tbar 97 t% Fe2Ot.

The high concentratiolr ofgoethitc close to the surface, malked by a high loss on ignition,

also decreases quickly at depth, suggesting thât a mâjority of contaminauts arc incorporated in

the goethite structure (Airrsworfh et al. 1985). Close to the contact with the dolomitic itabirite, at



IA

the lower levels of the Águas Claras mine, the contonts of P and Mn increase greatly (Fig. 9).

This fact is explained by the decreasing penneability obsei'ved in these zoues. This favors the

residual concenhation of the Mn oxides produced during the dissolution of tlÌe carbonates,

together with apatite, which is less soluble than dolornite.

Ptcliminary stuclies on the weathering ofthe Águas Clalas and Pico protoles indicate that

tlte fit'st steps of the plocess are iso-volumeftic. No substitution of quartz by goethite septa, as

describcd by Rarnanaidou (1989) and Ramanaidou et al. (1996) in the Capanema nrinc have yet

been identified. The continuity of the leaching process leads to the collapse of tl,e lock, with a

volume reduction of about 40%o and the generatiou of a significant porosity in the soft ore and

rich itabirite (Ribeiro et al. 1998; Ribeiro et al, 2002). The pores crcated during wea rering close

at the land surface, filled by goethite.

The weathering plocesses may also have hacl an importalìt lole o1r the gerresis of the

porosity of the hard ores, dissolving the accessory gangue rnineral and oxiclizing the residual

magnetite not oxidized by previous processes, as suggested by V ara:ão et al. (2002).

High-grade soft ores and iron-rich itabirites lepreserlt more than 80%o of the iron ore

resetves in the Águas Claras and Pico miues. This proves tlie irnportance of the weatbering

processes in the genesis of these o¡ebodies.

CONCLUSION

The Águas Claras ancl Pico iron mines arc two world-class mines hosted withiri Lower-

Claras orebody consists ofa roughly tabular-shaped lens forrned by high-grade iron ores hosted

within dolor¡itic itabirite. The high-grade oles cornprise more than 85% of soft ore, with the

remainder l5% formed by hard ore. Henratite is the rnain constituent of the ilon ores. Gangue

The Pico olebocly consists of a lenticular shape body hosted within a qualtz itabilite,

Abstract

The Cauê Formation of the paLeoproterozoic Minas Supergloup hosts banded ilon
formations (BIFs) of the Lake Superior type, locally called itabirites. Two major cornpositional

types of itabirite occur at the northwest of tho Quadrilátero Ferrífero (QF): clolornitic itabiritic

and quattz itabitite. The former consists of altemating dolomite-rich and hematite-ricli bands

while the latter is formed witli altemating quartz-rich and hematite-rich bands. Dolornite, quartz

and hematite are the major rninelalogical constituents, with accessories chlorite, sericite and

apatite.

The chemical colnposition of the itabirites is as sirnple as that of the BIFs which occurs

worldwide. At the dolomitic itabirite Fe2O3 plus CaO, MgO and LOI range from 95.8% f.o 97 .8%o

while at the quartz itabirite Fe2O3 plus SiO2 range from 94.4Y" to 99.6%". Both itabirites ale

highly oxidized and present Fe3*/(Fe2+ + Fe3*) ratios higher than 0.98, much greater than tlìe

average ratio of other paleoproterozoic BIFs. Tlace elements conceDtrations in itabirites are very

low arrd range from <l0 ppm (Y, Sc, Be, Cu, Ga, Ge, Rb, Nb, Mo, Ag, In, Sn, Cs, Ilf, Tl, Pb,
Bi, As, Cd, Th, U, Sb) to conconhations behveen l0 and 55 pprn (Ba, Sr, Zr', V, Ni, Zu, Co, Cr

and IREE).

Dolomite of the dolor¡itic itabirite sllows negative ¿ìr3C values varying frorn 1.5%o to

-0.8%o while the oxygeu isotope data displays òl8O values varying fron -12.4\/oo to -8.5%0. The

ôr3C values show an enrichrnent trend in l3C fiom the base to the top of the Cauê Forr¡ation,

pt'obably continuitrg upsection through the overlying stlomatolitic dolomites of the Gandarela

Fortnation. C aud O isotopes, REE signatures and Y/I:lo ratios indicate a marine origirr fol the

sediments of the dolomitic itabilite.

The IIREE enrichment pattcm exhibited by the itabirites shows a modem seawater IìEE

signâture overprinted by a hydrothermal pattem rnarke<l by positive Eu anomalies. A sÍotìg
colrelation between AlzO¡ and TiO, (r>0.9) inclicates a milìor terrigelrous compoûeut for the

chemically procipitated, rnarine sedinents of tlie Cauô Formation. Differences on the I'IREE

signatures of itabirites suggest that they precipitated ffom different sea'rr'ater depths, with the



82

clolor¡iLic itabirite precipitating in shallowcr waters receiving continental sediment laiden
watels while the quartz itabilite was precipitating in deeper waters, Sea-level fluctuatio¡s

caused by tnal'ine transgtession-regressions arc responsible for changes ou the compositiou of
seawatel dr.u ing the deposition of the Cauô Formatiol. These changes are expressed by
dolornitic-, qualtz- aud arnphibolitic itabirites, which represent lateral and vertical facies

transitions of carbonatic, cherty and shaly BIFs, respectively.

INTRODUCTION

Banded ilon formatiolls have lolg been an object of interest to rcscarch not only due to
theil' economic aspects, as tliey ale the najor source of irolt ole, but also due to their importance

for the understarding of atmosphele evolution, the chernical composition of the oceaus and the

appearallce of life on Earth. Trendall (2002) preselts an interesting aud updated summary of the

meaning of those rocks on the Precambrian stratiglaphic record, and his references introduce the

readers to this vast and complex theme.

The Cauê F'ormation of the Minas Supergroup is worldly known for hosting giant iron ore

deposits at the Quadrilátero Ferrífero of the Minas Gerais State il the southenl region of Brazil
(Fig. 1). lt is a classical protetozoic BIF deposited oD the continental shelf (Don 11, 1969),
classified as of the Superiol type, according to the scheme ofGross (1980). The Cauê Formation

itttegrates the group of the great Gondwalta BlFs together with the Carajás Formation of the

Grão Pará Group at the Alnazonic craton, the Kurlman and Penge Formations of the Transvaal

Supergroup in South Africa, the Mulaingiri Folnation of the Bababunclan Basin in hldia ancl the

BIFs of the Ilamersley Basin ili Australia.

Several geological ptocesscs have obliterated many of the pli1îary characteristios of the
original seditnents of the Cauê Formation thercfore origiuating the itabirites, a comûìon 1lalne

adopted ill Brazil for the metamorphosed alld oxiilized BIF. Three major cornpositioual types of
itabilite occur at the QF: quaÍz, dolomitic and amphibolitic (Dou It, 1969; Rosière et al., 1993).
Great doubts persist in the literature about the origin of this compositional variation and,
therefore, about the genesis of itabirites. Does it represent an original sedimentar.y facies
variatìon within the Minas Basin ol are itabirites ploducts of a later process after sedirnentation?

Dorr II (1969) corrclates the qtàrtz and dolomitic itabirites with BlFs of the oxide facies of
Jatnes (1954). I'le cotlsidereil the amphibolitic itabirite as a product of the contact mctamorphisrn

of cloloniitic itabitite by uealby granitio rocks. Beukes eL 'à1. (2002) attr:ibute tlìe genesis of the

dolomitic itabitite to be the result of hydrothennal metasomatism of the original cherty BIF



B3

during a hypogeue enrichrnent stage of the iron ore. Ver'íssirno (1999) aud Veríssirno et al.

(2002), however, interyleted the variations on the compositional type of the itabirite as
representrative of the original sedimentary facies variation. These authors describe the quartz and

amphibolitic itabirites at the Alegria Mine, East of the QF (Fig. 1), and correlate thern to the

oxide and silicate BlFs of Jarnes (1954).

The intelnatioual literature of itabirites of the Cauê Formation is very scarce and most wolk

was conducted during the 1960's and 1970's (e.g. Don II, 1969; Dorr Il 1973), Recently, Klein
and Ladeìra (2000) studied the petrology and geochernishy of sixteen itabirite sarnples collected

at foul different sites of the western QF. These authols interpleted rnûror element and REE
geochemistry of the itabirite to indicaLe precipitation and deposition frorn mixed Precamblian

seâwater arrd sub-oceanic hydrothermal fluids, but with no detailecl explanation for the origin of

the clolomitic and qtJattz itabirite. They also suggest that the preselce of hematite and abserrce of

magnetite or martite in the sarnples exalnined indicates that the hematite was fonnecl after
sedimentary feric oxide,4rydroxides during diagenesis or low-grade metamorphism. The
presence of martite alrd relicts of rnagnetite, as well as for-mations of hernatite after martite,

however, have long been desclibed in itabilite sarnples of the QF (Dorr 11, 1969; Rosière et al.,

1993). Their genesis of itabirites is therefole far frorn a satisfactory explanation.

The Águas Claras Mine is located on the northeast segment of tlìe Serra do Curral, North of

the QF (Fig.l), where the dolomitic and qtartz itabirite crop out. Mining of iron ore during tliirty

years has exposed a completc unweathered sequence of dolomitic itabirite. Several drill holes

intersect quartz itabirite in the north side of the mine. The quality of itabirite exposed on mining

benches and thousands of meters of drill core provide ideal sites to sanple all the sequence of tl,e

Cauô Founatioll in this part of the QF. This papel prese ts petrological and geochernical data of

46 samples of rocks collectod throughout the Cauê Fonnation, from its base to the transitioll

zorìe to dolomite of tlie overlying Ganclarela Formation. Our aims are to cornbine petlographic

and geochernical analyses to conlribute lor discussions about the genesis of the itabirites in the

QF. This study represent the first comprehelrsive chemostratigraphic analysis of the Cauê
Formation to dale. C and O isotopic analysis of dolornitic itabirite further constrain the
geochemistly of the fluid at the tirne of depositiou. Special attention is given to dolomitic
itabirite because this rock is the protore of the iron ore witliin this world class iron miuc (Spicr

et al.,2003: Viel er a1.. 1987).

The Minas Supergroup complises clastic sedirnents of the Caraça Gtoup at rts base, which

consist of an extensive qualtzose (Moeda Forrnatiou) and argillaceous (Batatal Fo nation)
formations. The Moeda Formation occurs in three facies: two alluvial coarse grained quartzite

arrd conglomerate sediments, and a fiDe-grained marine qluartzite and phyllite (Villaça, lgSl). Ìt

is conforrnably overlain by the Batatal Formation, wl,ich consists of sericitic phyllite with minor

gtaphitic phyllite. The Calaça Crr oup is irrterpreted to be a transgressive sequence deposited over

an old peneplancd sutface (Villaça, l98l). The Moeda Folmation was deposited under patalic to

stable shelf envitoDments wliile the Batatal Formation is an offshore sediment deposited on a

slowly subsidiug passive rnalgin continental shclf or platform (Dou II, 1969). The hansition
from clastic secliments of the Caraça Group to chernical sediments of the Itabira Group in the

northcm segtnent ofthe Serra do Curral is characterizecl by an argillaceous dolornite with lenscs

of metachert.

The Itabira Group comprises itabirites (BIFs) with minol dolomite and phyllite of the Cauê

Formation and carbonate rocks of the Gandarela Formation. Both unils are intergradational.

Itabirites of the Cauô Formation are generally lithologically sirnilar to most lnajol' oxide-facies

BIFs known worldwide (Don II, 1969). Carbonate rocks of the Gandarela Forrnation include
dolomites, limestones, dolomitic phyllite, dolomitic iron forrnation aud phyllite. They were

deposited in shallow water, ancl are locally rich in stromatolitic structures (Souza and Müller,

1984). Pb-Pb dating of this sfomatolitic dolomite yielded an age of 2420 + 19 Ma, which is
cousidered by Babinski et al. (1995) as a depositional age. Based on this upper lirnit, and

colìsidcrillg the Pb-Pl¡ ages on detrital zircons of the Moeda Forrnation which vary between 3.0

and 2.6 Ga, Babinski et al. (1995a) suggest that the deposition of the it¿birites of tlìe Itâbira

Group occuned between 2.6 and 2.4 Ga.

The upper unit of the Miuas Supergroup is the Piracicaba Group, which consists of
predominantly olastic sedirnents with minor chemical sodimetìts deposited in rnarine shallow

water and cleltaic environments. The Piracicaba Group overlies the ltabira Group generally with

structural conformity, but erosional disconformity has been locally found (Don II, 1969).

Altltough the tectolìic history of the QF rernains controversial (e.g. Alkmirn altd Mar-shak,

1998; Chernale Jr. et al., 1994; Davis ancl Hippert, 2000), there is a general conserìsus that thc

rocks of the Minas Supergroup were subjected to at least two main tectonic events cluriug the

Proterozoic. Accorcling to Chernale Jr. el aL (.1994) the first evelìt in the Transamazonian (- 2.1
Ma) was extensional aud resulted in lhe fonnatiou of Archean granite-gneiss clomcs and
nucleation of regional synclines iu the overlying Rio das Velhas and Minas supergtoups strata.



87

The second evelìt was compressional aud of Brasiliano age (-0.6 Ga). The Btasiliano event

resulted ili a west-velging fold-and-thrust belt causing invelsion, arnplification, tlanslation and

fotation of the basinal syicliues, affecting rnainly the eastem portion of the QF, and obliterating

many of the tectonic features of the extensional event.

Two main structural domains are recognized at the QF: an eastern high shain dornain with

thick shear zones and important thrust systems, and a western low slrain domain with well

preserved synclines discontinuously cut by discrete shear zolres aDd thrust faults (Rosière et al.,

2001). The deformational gradient comes along with a metamorphic zoning which increases

frotn west to east, aud is defincd by Iìerz (1978) as chlolite, biotite aud staurolite zones. Pires

(1995) redefincd tlìese metamolphic gracle zones as grunelite, cummingtonite, actinolite ancl

tremolite-antophylLite zones based on the cornpositional variation of tlie amphiboles of itabirite

and phyllite of the Itabira Group. Equilibrium temperatures range from 300 "C on tlìe \¡r'estefll

side to 600 oC on the eastem side ofthe QF, with pressules ranging fi'om 3 to 5 kbar respectively

(Pires, 1995).

MINERALOGY AND PETROGRAPHY

Sericitic Phyllite

Sericitic pþllite is a uniformly dark-grey very fine-grained phyllite (Fig. 4a). It is
latninated oti a fine scale (l-3 rmn thiok) and co¡sists of quartz ancl sericite with rninor biotite,
and shows a lepidoblastic texture witlì foliation defined by sericite and biotite. Large
porphyroclasts of quartz surror¡nded by sericite and quartz exhibting wavy extir,ction indicate

strong defoluration that this lock was submitted.

Argillaceous Dolomite

Algillaceous dolornite is a black, very fine-grained irnpure dolornite (Fig. 4b). Local
geologists name this rock dolornitic phyllitc because when weatheretl, argillaceous dolomite

resembles a phyllite. Ilowever, the high dolomite corltent altd absencc of any well-defined
lamination do not allow for the use of the telr¡ phyllite. Mineralogically, the argillaceous
dolor¡ite comprises dolornite (> 85 %), chlolite with minor quartz and rare pyritc (Fig. 8a-c).

Quartz occurs as aggregates showing sû'ong wavy extinction. The abseuce of hematite a¡d



97

magnetite irr argillaceous dolornite distinguishes this rock fi'om the overlying fenuginous

dolomite. Argillaceous<lolomite is strongly dcf'orrnecl ancl poorly foliated.

Granular Iron Formation

Granular iton formation is restricted to a oûe meter long lens which persists laterally for

tells of meters along the top of the argillaceous dolomite. Generally, it is not ilitemally banded,
but coarsening reducing clasts size is locally observed. The granulal texlure comprises hematite

clasts set in a cement or matrix of dolomite, sericite and chlorite (Fig, 5a-c). The clastic fraction

is usually peloidal, but may contain angular inlraclasts of hernatite-rich bands of itabirite. The

peloids ale louDdecl, subsphericâl grains of eithel itabirite or dolornite rangiltg from 0.2 to 5 mrn

iu diameter. Some peloids oontain concentric layers of hematite (Fig. 8f). Angular fragments are

lithologically similar to itabirite and form tabular fragments up to two centimcters lolg although
srnaller ones may be rounded arrd graded into peloids. Although the GIF is not weathered,

intlicated by the preservation of carbonate cemeDt, the clasts are stroltgly goethitized, which
poses a very intriguing question.

Ferruginous Dolomite

Femuginous dolor¡ite occurs at tlìe base and top of the dolornitic itabirite, and as meter

thick layers randomly distributed within thc dolornitic itabirite. Macroscopically and
microscopically the fcrruginous dolomite resernbles the dolornite bands of the dolorritic itabirite,

but lacks larger orystals of tabular hematite and martite colntnolt to dolomitic itabirite.
Fenuginous dolornite is cleep red to piuk, vely fine-grained, and poorly banded (Fig. 4e). It

consists of small cl'ystals of dolornite (average graiu size of 15 prm) with rnicrometer size
inclusiorrs of lìematite, which appear dusrlike within the dolomite crystals (Fig. 9a). 'fhese

hematite inclusious are respousible for the stroltg rod color of the rock- They are generally

concentrated on the nuclei of the dolomite crystals (Fig. 9b). Talc, chiorite ancl apatite occur as

accessory phases.

Dolomitic and Quartz itabirites

Mesobanding is the most striking macroscopic characteristic of itabirites at the QF.
Mesobanding is defined by altemating millimeter to decimeter hematite rich bands and
dolomite/quartz bands (Fig. 6b-d). Microbanding defined by altemating sub-millimeter hematite

and dolomitelquartz laminas are commonly observed within mesobands of itabirites (Fig.9c). In

dolomitic itabirite, the dolomitic bands consist largely of dolomite and up to 40Yo hematite (Fig.

9d). Talc, chlorite and apatite occur as accessory minerals. Thin laminas of apatite parallel to

banding are locally observed (Fig. l0a). Dolomite occurs as euhedral crystals varying from 2 pm

to 15 ¡rm intergrown with hematite and accessory minerals (Fig. l0b). Like the femrginous

dolotnite, microrneter hernatite inclusions form an iron dust within dolomite crystals (Fig. 9a).

Hematite in itabirites occurs as martite þseudomorphs of magnetite after oxidation), tabular



hematite arrd, locally, specularite. Specularite occurs along shear planes, parallel to or truncating

the banding. The hematitic bands are largely comprised of hematite with up to 20%o dolomite and

traces of talc, chlorite and apatite (Fig. l0 c-d). Hematite occurs as dense aggregates of martite

and tabular hematite with individual grains varying from 5 pm to l0 pm. Thicker hematite bands
preserve relict magnetite within martite crystals.

Quartz itabirite is macroscopically and texturally similar to dolomitic itabirite, but
mesobands rich of quaïlz replace dolomite (Figs. 10e, I la-b). Quartz is generally clean, without

hematite inclusions, and exhibits wavy extinction. Relicts of magnetite are locally observed
within martite crystals (Fig. I lc-d). When present, dolomite occurs intergrown with quartz (Fig.

10f). Apatite, chlorite and sericite occur as accessory phases intergrown with quartz and hematite

(Fig. l0 g-h) and, locally, as fine inclusions within quartz (Fig. ll e-Ð.The grain size of all
minerals is very frne (5 ¡rm to 25 pm). Quartz bands of the qtrantz itabirite consist of quartz with

varying proportions of hematite (up to 25%) and accessory minerals (i.e., apatite, chlorite and

sericite). Hematite-rich mesobands consist of dense aggregates of hematite with up to l5o/o of
quartz.

Quartz-Carbonate Rocks of the Transition Z-one to the Gandarela Formation

This group of rocks comprises quafiz itabirite bearing dolomite, cherty dolomite and
dolomite that occurs overlying quaftz itabirite at the transition zone to the Gandarela Formation.

The gradual appearance of dolomite and the disappearance of quartz and hematite in the quartz

itabirite characterize this group. Micro and mesobanding typical of itabirites is replaced by a
poor banding defìned by micaceous minerals. The typical clolornite of this zone consists of very

fine dolomite (average size of l5 ¡rm) with accessory sericite, chlorite and hematite (Fig. llg).
Locally the dolomite is enriched with chlorite, which comprises up to 30% of the rock. Chlorite

occurs as thin, millimeter laminas, which define conspicuous microbands (Fig. I lh). Talc with

minor chlorite and hematite fonn thin veins that crosscut these chlorite-rich bands.

The geochemical data of thirty six samples of tocks groupecl into fìve major lithological

groups and l2 separale analyses of dolornilic and hernatilic bancls of the dolomitic itabilile are

presented in Appenclixes I and 2. The triangular diagram of Figure 7 shows that clolomitic ancl
quartz itabirite have sirnple compositions, while sericitio phyllite, aryillaceous dolomite ancl

carbonate rocks of the transition zone to the Gandarela exhibit higher compositional variation.

Averages of major, ftace and REE are present in Tables 2 ancl 3 according to their lithotype

groups. We did not calculate the statistics for those variables with results always below or very

close to the detection lirnit. In cases where the results ofjust a few samples where below this

limit the statistics were calculated using half the detection limit for those samples. This
procedure was chosen to allow for attaching some distinctiou to those values which stood

slightly above the detection limit. It was used in all graphs presente<ì in this paper.

Major, trace and REE data of the Post Archean Australian Shale (PAAS) obtained by

Mclennan (1989) are used as normalization values in this paper. Occasionally, data of the Cl-

chondrite of Taylor and Mclennan (1985) is also used. We plesent REE patterns with Y inseltecl

bet\¡r'een Dy and FIo according to its ionic radius. We included Y to the lanthanides for
comparison with REE and Y studies of other iron fon¡ations. The Eu anomaly is definecl
quantitatively as:

The major element composiiion of the rocks examined is clearly related to the lithological

group that they belong to (Fig. 7), This is best observed by plotting the chemical atìalyses as

function of stratigraphy (Fig. l3a). The compositional variation along the stratigraphy within

each inclividual group is less obvious. FeO ancl TiO2 contents are highü in the argillaceous

dolomite, but significantly reduced to\¡/ards the contact with the dolomitic itabirite where they

remain approximately constant. The CaO and MgO contents are reduced towards the contact

with the quartz itabirite, while the Fe2Or content is increased. P2O5 contents increase from the

base towards the middle of the quaftz itabirite, but this trend can be oblitolatecl by the high P2O5

content of sample P3-23.

SiOz, AlzO¡ and K2O are the major constituellts of the sericitic phyllite with average

contents of 63.3%, 18.6% ar'd 5.gYo respectively. This rock is also characterized by high TiO,
(averagc of 0.8%) and low CaO contents (average of 0.1%).

The argillaceous dolomite group exhibits the greatest compositional variation of major

elements when compared with other lithological groups. This major olement variation is
attributed to the presence of lenses of metachert and quartz itabirite analyzed with the dolomitc.

CaO (average of 24.4Yo ranging from 22.6Yo to 25.4Yo) and MgO (average of 15.6% ranging
from 14.8% lo 16.7%) are the main const.ituents togethel with SiO2, which ranges from 4.8o% to
19.2o/o (avenge of l3%). Loss on ignition (LOI) is high (average of 38.4%) ranging from 35.7%

to 39.\Yo. This sample group has higher contents of Al:O: than the itabirite and carbonate-rocks

gronps (average of 1.3%), but an order of magnitude less AlzO: than the sericitic phyllite. It is
also characterized by the highest weight percent FeO of all sample groups, with an average 4.3

% FeO and ranging from 3.3 o/o to 5.5'yo FeO. The organic carbon content of this group, although

very low (average of 0. 1%), was the highest of all studred gloups.

Bulk analysis indicates dolomitic itâbirite has the highest iron contents among all

chemically classified groups. Iron contents tange f'rom 39.'7%o to 67.6%" Fe2O3 and average

48.9o/o Fe2O3. CaO and MgO contents average l4.4Yo and l0.3o/o, respectively. LOi produced by

loss of COz from dolomite is highly variable and may be as high as 27 %o of the rock weight.

SiO2 contents are very low because samples containing quartz itabirite were not analyzecl. Al2O3

contents range from <0.1 and 0.8% (average of 0.3%), ancl Na2O, KzO and TiO2 contents are

very low (average of 0.02o/o). P2O5 contents range from 0.05% to 0.19Yo and average 0.12Vo.FeO

contents in dolomitic itabirite of the QF are very low (0A% - 0.9% FeO) when comparecl to FeO

contents of other BIF's worlcl wicle. The Fe2O3/(Fe2O3 + FeO) ratio for the dolomitic itabirite
ranges from 0.98 to 0.99, which indicates a very high degree ofoxidation.

Chemical analyses of dolomitic and hematitic bands confrm petlographical analyses and

show that, although there is a predominance of dolomite ol hematite irr their respective bands,

both minerals are always present. Therein the dolomitrc bands exhibit higher contents of CâO,

MgO and LOI than the hematitic bancls, but with thc Fe2Or content reaching tp to 24Yo.
Hematitic bands have a Fe2O3 content of up to 85% with CaO and MgO contents reaching 9%

and 60% respectively. The FeO content of the dolomitic bancls range from 0.2o/o to l.5Yo (average

of 0.7%), with the Fe2O3/(Fe2O3 + ¡'e6; ratio ranging between 0.73 and 0.97 (average of 0.91).

In the hematitic bands the FeO content ranges from 0.2Yo to 0.5o/o (average of 0.3%), with much

highcr Fe2O3/(Fe2O3 + FeO) ratios ranging from 0.99 to 1.00. Lower Fe2O3(Fe2O3+FeO) ratios



111

observed in the dolornitic bands inclicate the presence ofFe'' in the dolomite composition, which
is confirmed by EMP analyses. Otherwise the high Fe2O3/(Fe2O3 + FeO) ratio obseryed in
hematitic bands confit'ms the high clegleo ol' oxidalion of the dolornitic itabirite as inclicatecì
petrographically by the significant martitization of magnetite,

Qìrârtz itabirite consists essentially of FezO¡ (average of 55.7 %) and SiO2 (average of
41.7 %). CaO, MgO ancl LOI are very low, generally lower than 0.5%. FezOl(FezO¡ + FeO)

ratios range from 0.97 to 1.00, which is also an indication ofaclvanced oxiclation of this itabirite.

The lithological variation observed at the transition zone from the Cauê to the Batatal

Formations is refleclecl by the major element data. SiO2 (average of 26.6 %) and FezO: (average

of 19.7 %) are the main componcnts followed by CaO (average of 15.1 %), MgO (average of

10.6 %) antl LOI (avelage of 23.8 %). Al2O3 (average of 0.7 %) ancl TiO2 (average of 0.05%)

contents are gleater than itabirites and comparable to those ofargillaceous dolomite.

Ranges and strâtigraphic variation oftrace elements

The concentration of trace elements in all samples is generally very low <10 ppm (Fig.

14a, Table 2). When compared to the PAAS contents only the sericitic phyllite shows sirnilar

concentrantions, except for Sr and As contents, which al'e much lower (Fig. lab). The other

lithologies are vety poor chemical secliments.

The argillaceous dolomite from the base of the Cauô Formation and the dolomite from

the transition zone to the Gandarela Formation have very sirnilar trace elements concentrations

while the concentrations of the minor elements are much lower than those of the PAAS. The

rnain clifference between the PAAS and the argillaceous dolomite ate the higher Cu, Rb, Cs,

IREE ancl Th (average of 13, 10,0.4, 35 and 2 ppm, respectively), and lower Zn (<I pp-,
much lower than that of PAAS) contents of the algillaceous dolornite.

Quartz ancl dolomitic itabirite contain low concenlrations of t¡ace elements when
compared with the PAAS, except for Sb (average of 3 ppm) contents, which are higher in the

quartz itabirite (Fig. lab), The Rb, Cs, flf and Th contents ato particularly low in both itabirites,
Figure l4c shows fhe average trace elements contents of quartz ltabiíte normalizecl to clolomitic

itabirite. The latter is richer in Sr, Y, Cu, Zn, Pb, Th and Cr while the fo¡mer has higher contents

of Sb and Cd.

Figurc l4d shows the average trace elements contents of the hematitic bands of the
dolomitic itabirite norrnalizecl to the average contents of the dolomitic bands highlighting any

diffe¡enccs betweon thern. The dolomitic bands have higher Ba (2x), SL (4x), Y (2x), Cu (l0x),

Nb (2x), IREE (2x), Pb (5x) and Th (3x) contents than the hematitic bancls. Flematitic bands,

otherwise, have higher Zr (2x), Y (4x), Ni (2x), Zn (2x), Rb (2x), Cs (4x) ancl Ccl (13x) contenrs

than those of the dolomitic bantls.

Unlike the major element chemistry which clearly distinguishes each lithotype, the trace

element concentrations are not as clearly indicative of a particular rock type (Fig. l3b-c).
However, foul major groups of elements show some trencl within and between each of the
lithotypes. Ni, Nb and Cr conoentration are very low throughout the sequence. C:u,Y, Zr, Ba,

IREE and Th exhibit higher average contents in the argillaceous dolomite; Zn, Sr, and Pb are

characteristically associatecl with clolomitic itabirite, and Cd, Sb, Ge ancl to a lesser extent As, V
and, Zr have a strong relation with quartz itabirite.

The clistribution of minor elements along the sequence sho\¡/s a remarkâble feature at the

passage from dolomitic to quartz itabirite, when contents of the last group mentioned above

increase abruptly. After this point the contents of those elements reduce graclually and remain

constant along the transition zone to the Gandarela Formation. Another important feature
observecl in Figure l3d is the abrupt change observecl in the FezO3/(FezO¡ + FeO) ratio at the
transition from argillaceous dolomite to dolomitic itabirite. Less clear, but still remarkable, is the

gradual reduotion found in the IREE, Y and U contents from fhe base of the dolomitic itabirite

towards the top of the transition zone to the Gandarela Formation.

Some linear interelement correlations

The results of some linear interelement correlatiolrs of major and trace elements are
dsiplayed in Table 4. These elemcnt-element coruelations include the total dataset for samples of
the Cauô Formation (disregarding satnples of dolomitic and hematitic bancls, Table 4a) and only

itabirite samples (Table 4b). We have not inchrded results below or close to detection limit.

Some significant interelement correlations are showecl in Figure 15.

For the entire set of samples of the Cauê Formation, very positive correlation exists for

CaO ancl MgO (10.99), LOI (rl,00), MnO (r=0.91) ancl Sr' (r:0.72), which represent the gr.oup
of elements present in the dolornite cornposition. A12Oj correlates very well with TiO2 (r:0,93),

Manikyamba, 1998) to inclioate a cletrital contlibution cftning formation of prirnary BIF. IREE
correlates well with Th (t-0.tì3) ancl Y (r=075). Fe1¡¡1.does not couolrÌLe with any element accept

variety of rocks within the set of samples studied, the absence of goocl linear interelement

is studied separately, the differences on the interelement correlations between them (if existent)

turn more evident, as is observed in Figute 15.

REE and Y abundances (REEY) of all samples are listed in Appendix I and avelages of
each major lithological group are presented in 1'able 3. PAAS normalized REEY patterns of all

samples are also divided into the five groups shown in Figure l6a*, With the exception of
sericitic phyllite, all lithologies are characterizecl by depleted IREE (ranging from 8-35 ppm).

The sericitic phyllite shows an average IREE of 227 ppm which is slightly higher than
that of the PAAS (185 ppm; Mcl.emran, 1989). Although they show a LREE enrichmenr
(La,|/b=1.38), tho contonts of heavy rare earth elements (HREE) are failly closc to those of the

PAAS, plotting as a flat pattem (Fig. l6e). The REEY patcern of the sericitic phyllite is identical

to that of the Post-Archean shale as demonstrated when these rocks are plottecl against C-l

chondrite (Fig. l6f), except lor a slightly more positive Eu anomaly t'or the PAAS (average
Eu/ELr*:1.24), possibly related lo the presenoe o1'felclspar in the phyllite.

The argillaceous rlolomite samples show depleted IREE (average of 35 ppm), but less

clepleled thân that of the overlying itabirite ancl clolomite. All samples display a similar REEY
pattem (Fig. l6c) with HREE enrichment (LalYb:0.52), middle rare earth element (MREE)

enrichment (LalSm:0.76) ancl no fracfionation of HREE (Sn/Yb:I.03). They show strongly
positive Eu anomalies (Eu/Eu-:1.84), but do not exhibit Ce or Y anomalies, exccpt for sample

Ml39 whioh ilísplays Ce/Ce-=0.90.

Samples of clolomitic itabirite show an average IREE of l4 ppm with concentration
ranging between 7 ppm to 40 ppm. REEY patterns of all samples are very similar (Fig. l6d) and

show HREE enrichment (LalYb:0.27). LalSm (-0.62) anrl Sm/Yb (:0.45) ratios for dolimitic

itabirite indicate endchment of heavier REE elernents in both the light ancl heavy REE
categories. Sample MAC06 shows a shong La anomaly. Significantly higher concentrations of

material. All samples display strong positive Eu (Eu/Eu*:I.65) and Y (Y/Y":I.59) anomalies

Dolomite-rich bands of dolomitic itabirite are less depleted (average IREE of l9 ppm) than

C and O Isotopes

The forly five analysed dolomite samples of the clolomitic itabilite of the Cauê Formation

show negalive ôl3c values varying from -2,5%o to '.0.8%o while the oxygen isotope clata clisplays

ôr8O valnes varying from -72.4%oo to -8.5%o (Table 5). In a stratigruphic sense, there is a
depletion in the l3C content of dolomitic itabirite at the base of the sequence, with fernrginous

dolomite exhibting lower oontents (Fig. l2). Dolomitic itabirite becomes less depleted in r3C up

to the midclle of the sequence, where there is another depletion trend. ôl3C keeps a lower ancl
relatively constant carbon-13 isotopic cornposition from approximately the middle to the top of
the dolomitc itabirite. In contrast to l3C, r8O contenis show a different trencl. l8O increases liom
the base of dolomitic itabirite up to the miclclle of the sequence, and then continuously decrease

up sequence. Close to the top of the clolomitic itabirite, dolomite becomes more enriched in the

heavier isotope, again. ôl8O ancl ôl3C exhibit similar trends along the sequence, with ôl8O
showing small shifts, maybe due to its three order of magnitucle higher sensitivity to alteration in

diagenetic environment than ô13C (Banner antl Hanson, 1990).

Figure 12 displays the òr3C and ôr8O data obtainecl by Bekker er al. (2003) in
strornatolitic clolomites in the uppet part of the Gandarela Formation. ôl8O values of the
dolomitic itabirite and those of the stromatolitic itabirite are similar and exhibit similar orders of
variation. Most samples of the Cauê Folmation ancl Ganclarela Formation have ôl8O values
above -10.5 per mil consistent with those found in well-preserved Paleoproterozoic catbonate

successions (Bekker et a\.,2003; Veizer et al., 1992; Veizer et al., 1990; Veizer et al., 1989). r3C

contents of the dolomitic itabirite are lower than those of dolomite of the Gandarela Formation.

Tlre most negative ô13C values occur at the base of the seqnence (-2.4 pu mil), gracling up-
section into values arouncl -1.7 per mil. Red dolomite sampled by Bekker et al. (2003) a[ the

base of the Ganclarela Formation in the Gandarela Fann (Fig. 1) clisplays õl3C values ranging
from -1.3 to -1.0 per mil. These authors found positive ð13C values (aronnd + 0.4 per mil) for

dolomite at the top of the Gandarela Formation. Carbon isotopic data of the Cauê Formation

obtainecl in thís stutly combined with data for dolomite rocks of the Gandarela Formation
intlicates a positive trend (with slight variations) in ôr3C values within the rocks of the Minas

Supergroup. Positive carbon isotope excursions in seawater composition are generally
interpreted as inclicating high relative burial rates of organic matter and accompanying increase

in the oxygen production (Derry et al., 1992; Karhu and Holland, 1996; Kaufman etal., 1997).
The record of a positivc trentl in the ðl3C values cluring the interval of deposition of the Itabira

Group between 2.6 and 2.4 Ga is re levant to our current unclerstaniling of global climates
during the Paleoproterozoic.
