Comparison with other iron-formations

The average major and trace clements contents of the dolornitic and quartz itabirite ofQF
ale compaLecl with BIFs of the Carajás Fotmation (Linclenmayer et al.,2001; Macambira and
Schrank, 2002), the Kaapvall supergroup (Klein and Beukes, 1992) ancl the Llamersley Gror.rp

(Klein and Beukes, 1992) in FigLrre 17. The avetages were recalculated without the t,OI,
according to Klein and Beukes (1992), to allow for comparisons between metamorphic ancl
mmetamorphic BIFs. These authots assume that metamorphic reactiorrs are essentially
isochemicals for major elements except for HzO and CO:.

A very rematkable feature of dolomitic an<l quartz itabirites that is obsetvecl only in the

QF and Carajás BIFs, which distinguishes thern from the others BIFs, is their high Fe2O3 ancl

low FeO contents (Fig. l7a). The Fe2O3/FeO ratio in BIFs from Issua, Transvaal ancl Ilamersley

is lower thalr or close to l, while in Brazilian BIFs this ratio is much higher reaching an avcÌage
of39 in Carajás and values arouncl 70 in itabirites of the QF.

The dolomitic itabirite shows a chemical composition that is very ctifferent frorn the
others BIFs as a result of its different mineralogical composition. The SiOz content of this rock is

very low due to the almost complete absence of qtrartz. CaO and MgO, however, showecl the
highest contents ofall BIFs considerecl, which reflects the presence of dolomite. The other major
elements are similar to those observed in other BIFs. The quartz itabirite shows a very sìmple

major element composition that consists basically of SiO2 and Fe2O3, with TiO2, CaO, MgO,
MnO, NazO, K2O and P2Os contents being lower than those of the other BIFs found worldwide.

The only difference obseffed is in the Al2O3 content, which, although very low, is higher in eF
BIF than BIFs of the Transvaal but sirnilar to Carajás BlFs.

A comparisott of tl'ace element composition in BIF is problematic because [here is no
data available in the literature of BIFs for a number of elements presented here. Figure l7b
shows that the trace elements composition of itabirites is similar to that of other BIFs founcl
worldwide. All of ther¡ contain very low h'ace element concentrations when comparecl with
PAAS (Fig. l7c). The Ni, Cu, Zn and Rb contents of the dolomitic ancl quartz itabirite are lower

and U contents are higher than other BIF's.

Figure 18 shows the C and O isotopic composition of dolomitic itabirite is distinct whe¡

compared to other BIFs consiclered above. The values of the ôl3c and ôl8o are quite similar to
those obtaine<l by Rivers (1998) for carbonates of the Wittenoom Formation of the Hamersley

Basin, ancl by Sial et al. (2000) ancl Bekker er al. (2003) to srromatolitic dolomites of the
Gandarela Formation of the Minas Basin. Thcse similarities and the grach.ral l3C enrichrnent up-

128



129

section from the base of the Cauê Formation to the top of the Gandarela Formation suggest that

clolomites of the Cauê Formation preserve the deposi[ional catbon isotope cornposition, likely

reflecting the cornposition of seawatet solutions.

The values of òl3C of dolomitic itabirite are slightly lower than those of normal marine

carbonates, which are typically characterizecl by ôl3C values ofc. -1, but higher than those founcl

for BIFs of the Flamersley ancl Transvaal basin. The higher depletion oflrc in BIFs of these
basins is attributed to their forrration in an isotopically depleted water rnass (Beukes et at., 1990;

Kaufman et al., 1990). Accot<ling to the models ofBeukes et al. (1990) and Becker and Clayton

(1972), early Ptoterozoic oceans vr'ere stratified with rospecl to the isotopic signature of
dissolved COz, with a lower ocean water mass clepleted in lrC. Upwelling woulcl bring deep,
ânoxic waters to shelves where siderite with isotoplc composition near -5 pel mil formed below
the chemocline, while limestones with isotopic composition near -l per mil formed in shallow,
nea¡-shore envil'onment. The l3C enrichment from BIFs of the Transvaal basin to BIFs of the

Cauê Formation, with intermediate l3C contents in BIFs of the Hamersley basin, suggests
variation in the seawater carbon isotopic composition within each of the basins or shelf
environments where BIF's were precipitated. BIFs of the Transvaal basin have a higher
oontribution of light carbon in COz f¡om deep, anoxic seawater, whereas BIF of the Cauê
Formation which are enilched in isotopically heavy carbon would have a higher contribution of
shallow, oxygenated waters. REE data of the dolomitic itabirite support cleposition of BIF in
neat-shore environments (see discussion below).

Most authors agr-ee that BiFs are chemical sediments fonned by the precipitation of ilon

and silica from solutions consisting of a mixture of seawatq with hydrothermal fluids, with
various degrees of contamination by terrigenous sediments canieil by rivers or winds, or
emanated from volcanic activities (e.g. Arora et al., 1995; KaLo et al., 1998; Kimberley, 1989;

Klein and Beukes, 1989). Hydrothermal fluids woulcl be produced in the convection cells along

micl-ocean ridges and back-arc spreacling centers, where a fluid rock-interaction takcs place irr a

reducing environment with ternperatures reaching > 300'C and pll staying between 2 and 4

Gandarela



132

(Bau and Möller, 1993). Convection cutrents would transport the hyclrothelmal fluicls mixecl

with deep seawa[et up to the continental shelf where they would be plecipitated. This model is

based on comparisons of the REE signàture ofBIFs with that ofdeep hyclrothermal cleposits. The

patterns are essentially the same which show pronounced positive Eu anomalics ancl depletion in

the light REE (Danielson etal., 1992; Derry and Jacobsen, 1990).

The geochemical signature of BIFs helps to understanci their depositional
paleoenvironment. Howevor, the signature can be maskecl by a high clegree of terrigenous
contamination, or obliteratecl by later diagenetic and metamorphic processes, which woulcl lead

to wrongful interpretations. The itabirites of the Cauê Formation are the product of at least t,¡,/o

teotonic events ancl metamorphism to green schist facies. 'Ihe interpretation of the geochemical

data for reconstructing a palaeoenvironmcntal ancl clepostional model requires analysis to
determine how preservecl are the primary geochemical signatures. To justify our genetic model

below, we discuss how our mineralogical, petrological and geochemical clata of the Cauô
Formation reflects that of primary BIF.

The question of terrigenous contamination

Bat¡ and Möller (1993) shol¡/ed the REE in the chemically precipitated component of
BIFs is a proxy for the compositiou of contemporanoous seawater, bringing useful insights into

the chemistry of ancient sea water, and the secular variations of the atmosphere-hydrosphere-

lithosphere system. These REE pattents, however, are significantly modified by tenigenous
contaminants, largely because REE abundances may be more than two orders of magnitude
hìgher in clastic detritus than in seawatel' plecipitates (Arora et al., 1995; Bau, 1993). The
interpretation of REE patterns nceds, therefore, a very careful monitoring of tenigenous
contamination.

ln BIFs of the Hamersley and Transvaal shales and lutites are consiclerecl clastic
contaminants with a primary volcanogenic origin (Beukes et al-, 1990; Ewers and Monis, 1981;

Monis, 1993). These rocks consist essentially of stilpnomelane, and are chemically distinct from

stilpnomelane in their host BIFs by higher contents of Al2O:, TiOz, KzO and Zr (Florstmann and

llälbich, 1995). A positive correlation between the TiOz and AlzO¡ in BIF of the Hamersley
Province was intetpreted by Ewers and Morris (1981) as inclicative of clastic contamination.
However, this same relationship was not established by Florstmann ancl Hälbich (1995) in the

Tlansvaal BIFs.



133

Itabirites of the Cauô Formation at the Águas Claras mine clo not contain interlayerecl

shalcs or lutite as mentioned above. Flowever, volcanic contribution to the chemical sediments of
lhe Cauê Fotmation in the QF has very recently been suggested by Suckau et al. (oral
information). The aluminous micaceous minerals found both in the argillaceous clolomite and in

the dolomite of the transition zone to the Gandarela Formation, sometimes forming thin laminas

(Fig. I l h), may be terrigenous. The very strong positive correlation between Al2O3 and TiO2 on

the whole set of the samples studied (Fig. l5) suggest contribution of a tenigenous component

during depositior, of the Cauê Formation, and we suggest the aluminous micaceous minerals

observed in all lithologies are the major contaminants. Very low KzO contents suggest a minirnal

amount of terrigenous contamination, which is comparable to contamination levels in BIF's of

Dolomitization and the Genesis of the Dolomitic Itabirite

The distribution of dolomito in the dolomitic itabirite of the Cauê Formation ancl in the

dolomite and marbles of the Gancla¡ela Formation suggest that the original scdiments of these

rocks were largely dolomitized. Although in specific environments, where lhe seawater is hotter

and has higher PCO2, higher Mg/Ca ratio, lower SOq2' ancl organic acicl effects, the clirect

precipitation of dolomite is possible (Tucker and Wright, 1990), it is more probable that the
dolomite found in QF results from the dolomítization of earlier carbonates, a common process in

the Proterozoic. According to Tucker and Wright (1990) dolomitization generally appeals to be

an early near-surface phenomenon, where CaCO: minerals precipitated on the seafloor can be

dolomitized by seawater with a high clolomitizing potential. Dolomite is a common mineral

component in BIFs, where it is usually associated with ankerite and calcite (e.g. Arora et al.,
1995; Dymek and Klein, 1988; Ewers and Morris, l98l; Floran ancl Papike, 1978; Klein ancl
Beukes, 1989). In the Lake Superior region there are unmetamorphosed BIFs corrposed only of
dolomite ancl iron minerals (e.g. Klein and Fink, 1916;Perry Jr. et al., 1973). The same occrrs at

the Nabberu basin, westem Australia (Flall and Goode, 1978).

It seems likely that the dolomitic rocks of the Cauê ancl Gandarela Formation result from

clolomitization of earlier carbonates during the diagenesis. Beukes et al. (2002), howevcr,
consider the dolomitlc itabirite as tho result of the desilisification and carbotiatization of quartz

itabirite through a hyclrothermal process, without presenting any evidence for this process. There

is no field evidence to support this paragenetic sequence. On the contrary, the coexistence of
quartz and<lolomitic itabirite is locally observed in drill cores ancl outcrops of the Águas Claras

Mine sometimes forming a triply bancted rock (Fig. 6c). Quartz and dolomite are commonly



137

intergrown in metachert, dolomite and itabirite without displaying any evidence of metamorphic

reaction or hyclrother mal substitution (Fig. 8d).

Dolomitic itabirite and dolomite of the Cauê Fonnation occur throughout the Seua do

Curral, along c. ll0 Km of extcnsion, indrcating a regional dislribution for these rocks, It is
likely that a regional hydrothermal process of clolomitizatiorì ofthe quartz itabirite, as suggested

by Beukes et aI. (2002), would leave some indication of its occunence, which was not observed

to this day. Based on the fielcl relâtions, pettographical and mineralogical observations,
geochemical ancl isotopic clata, we considel that dolomitic itâbirite of the Cauê Formation are

carbonate sediments modified by a clolomitization process which occurred cluring diagencsis,

insteacl of a product of hydrothermal metasomatisrn of the quartz itabirite. We also consider that

these carbonate sediments represent a lateral and vertical facies variation of the cherty sediments

from which the quartz itabirite originated.

Y/Ho ratios of the dolomitic itabirite provicle further constraints to their origin. Modern

seawater has an Y/Ho ratio (>44) that is substantially highel than chondrite (26-28). The vast

majority of geologic materials, inclucling all volcanic rocks ànd clastic sediments, liowever, have

contlritic ratios (Nozaki et al., 1997). Sampled dolomitic itabirite have Y/FIo ratios ranging from

34 lo 52 with an average of 42 (Fig.20 ancl Table 3), suggesting the dolomite precipitated from

seawatet.

A marine origin for the dolomitic itabirite is also indicated by the C and O isotopes,
which present ôl3C and öl8O couelated with that of the stromatolitic carbonates of the Gandarela

Folmation of the Minas basin, and v/ith the Wittenoom Formation of the lÌamersley basin (Fig.

l8). Carbon isotope data of the Cauê Formation are similar to those found in all stuclied marine

carbonatcs older than ca.2.32 Ga supporting the interpretâtion that they are seawater precipitatcs

slightly rnoclified by diagenetic and metamorphic alteration.

The High Degree of Oxidation

The dolomitic itabirite of the Cauê Formation has Fes u/(Fe2'+Fe3*) r'atios raging from

Comparison of Fe3'/(F€2.!+Fe3 ') ratios of magnetite (0.67) ancl hematite (1.0) with those

The hematite present iu itabilitcs, however, tesults from sevoral gsological ptocesses that

Several authors (Don II, 1969; Pires, 1995; Pires and Frost, 2004; Rosière et al., 1993;

In the quartz itabirite with metachclt lenses at the transition zolte fiom argillaceous

hematite, with specularite forming in higher deformed areas.

The origin of the fluids responsible for the pewasive marttlizatìon of magnetitc in

A srnall participation of terrigenous sediments in the composition of the water solutions

(e.g. Beukes and Klein, 1990; Gnaneshwar Rao and Naqvi, 1995; Khan ancì Naqvi, 1996). The

nature and origin of the terrigelìous seclirnents in BIFS of the QF is still unclear. The terrigenous

component maybe suspencled clastic material 01' a clissolvecl component of river waters, or
possibly volcanic ash carried by winds to the ocean. The mineralogical composition of itabiritcs

and REE contents are higher at the base of the dolomitic-quartz itabirite sequence and decrease

from shallow to deeper waters. Beside to suggest that sedimentation of dolomitic itabirite

Better constrâints of the source of sediments ancl the palaeodepositional environment of

dolomitic and quartz itabiritcs show that both tocks precipitated from seawater mixed with

Table 3). Different REE f¡actionation pâttems of dolomitic and qurtz indicate variation in the
composition of this hydlothelmal-scawatel aqueous solution (Fig. l6a and d ). This variation

most likely reflects the location of BIFs relative to hydrothermal vents and continent, ancl

temperature hydrothermal fluids. Highel temperature fluids leach more Elr from ocean-floor

hydrothermal fluids, or with the contlibution of fluids with high temperatures, because the

Kato et al. (1998) studying the REE fractiouation patlern irì BIFs ancl associated

ferruginous/siliceous mudstone in micl-Archean rocks of the Pilbara craton, Western Australia,

from the exposed continental cßst or island arcs. Once sericitic phyllite and all rocks of the Cauê

Formation shows positive En anomaly (Fig. 16), one could associate these anomalies iu

Therefore, it is leasonable to infe¡ that the gradual decreasing ofthe Eup¡¡s anomaly observed in

finid temperature, or to a highel mixtu¡e of it with the seawater.

Elderfield et al. (1990) showed that the (Sn/Yb)m¿s ratio and pLI are negatively
coruelated in seawater. The highcr (Sm/Yb)r,ees ratio of the quartz itabirite (and consequently its

flatter REEY patterl) is therefore consistent with a lower pH solution frorn which silica

and Mö1ler 1993). Differences on the REEY pattem of clolornitic and quartz itabirites shown in

Figure 16 probably reflect variation of the pII of seawater, with dolomitic itabirite having a

acidic) bottom water.

The plecipitation of chert in the seawater is inclependent of the Eh conclitions (Kato and

Nakamura,2003), and is depenclent only on the concentration of silica in solutiou and the pFI of

the solution. Local variation on the pH and conoentration of silica in solution of the seawater

clastic input would control the tree major compositioual types of BlFs observed in the QF. The

co-precipitation of cherl and carbon¿te petrographically obseruecl in samples of metachert and



142

dolomite suggests that the seclimeirtation of the itabjrites occuned very close to the limit of

stability of both minerals. Small variations on the pFI oonclitions would therefore favor the

An additional feature of the REEY pattern of the itabirites is the negative Cep¡¡5
anomaly. Ce behavior in aqueous solutions is stlongly dependent on the redox conditions and it

Variation of the magnitude of the Cepaas anomalies in both the clolomitic and quarlz

The dolomitic and quartz itabidte would then represent two clistinct sedimentary facies of the

The Depositional Model

Gross ( 1983) suggested that iron formations intetbeclclccl with dolornite, quartzite, shales

and volcanic rocks were cleposited on continental shelves close to craton malgins. The r.rpwalcl

lithological gradation ft'om conglomeratic qr.rartzite to phyllite to BIFs to stromatolitic dolomite

led Renger et al. (1994) to suggest that sediments of the Minas basin werc clepositecl in a
continetttal shelf environmcnt. Changes in water depth evidencecl by lithological variations in the

Minas Supergroup indicate that marine transgression-rogression cycles acted during the
cleposition of the Minas basin.

Deposition of BIFs cluting marine transgrcssions is suggested for BIFs of the I-Iamersley

basin and the Transvaal basin (Klein and Beukes, 1989; Simonson, 1996; Simonson et al.,
1993), both contemporâneous with the Minas basin (Babinski et al-, 1995a). Klein ancl Beukes
(1989) associated the deposition of the KLr¡uman BIF to a major. transgressive event that
extensively submerged the Kaapvaal craton. Renger et al. (1994) ernphasized the close
similarities between the Kapvaal basin and the Minas basin, ancl suggestecl that the Cauê

Fotmation is the counteryârt of the Kuruman Formation. The lithological variation in the Minas

Supergroup inclicate that there were progressive desper water conclitions from the Moecla

Formation [o the Cauê Formation associated with h'ansgression, and indicates that BIFs in the

Cauê Fonnation weÍe also deposited during a marine transgression that blanketed the São
F¡ancisco craton.

Differently from the Kaapvaal craton, which was completely submerged, the continuous

contlibution of terrigenous sediments to BIF's cluring the sedimentation in QF, as previously

discusseci, suggest the existence of emergecl areas of the São Francisco craton that coulcl act as

source fot these secliments. Higher terrigenous contribution occurs in the al.gillaceous dolomite at

the base of the Cauê Formation and in the dolor¡ite of the transition to the Gandarela Formation.

Geochemical data suggests that itâbirites have a very low terrigenous component, which
indicates sedimentation probably occurred during the climax of the marinc transgression.

Additional support of marine transgression-regression cycles during the tleposition of the

Cauê Formation comes from the occurtence of GIF in the transition ffom argillaceous dolomite

to fenuginous dolomite. GIF is consiclerecl to have formed by submarine erosion ancl the
cleposition of earlier formecl BlFs. Reglession-transgressiou cycles representing sea level
changes are generally responsible for such erosion, whioh result in the deposition of e¡oded

143



144

material close to BIF (Klein and Beukes, 1989; Morris, 1993; Simonson, l9g5). When the
quieter conclitions prevailecl again, the cleposition of BIFs took ovel anfl produced short soale
latelal ancl verlical hansiLions. The GIF interbeddecl wi[h argillaceous clolomite exhibits ïìning
upwards graded bedcling, whioh indicates increasing sea levels. It was formed flom the erosion
ofolder quartz itabirite, but its peloids are cemented by carbonate, which inclicates the existence

ofuot orrly valiations in the sea level, but also changes in the seawatel. composition.

Regression-ttansgression cycles woulcl strongly affcct the bulk composition of seawater

in a more restricted BIF clepositional basin. We suggest these bulk compositional changes iu
seâwatü are tepresented in the QF by a lithological variation in the itabi¡ites, irith dolomitic-,
quartz- and amphibolitic-itabirites representing cal'bonatic, cherry ancl shaly facies of the Cauô
basin, respectively. Lateral and vertical transitions between clifferent lithotypes woulcl mean

sedimentologic facies changes in response to the local variation in the aqueous solution
composition, maybe related to changes in water deptl1, pl-I and input of clastic components.

The lack of regional maps showing facies changes within the itabirites of the cauô
Formation makes paleoenvironmental studies ancl the elaboration of clepositional moclels
extl'emely difficult. Recent exploratory works caffiod out by MBR in the eastern limb of the
Moeda syncline (Fig. l) show majol differences in the stratigraphy of the cauê Formation (Fig.
22). In the Águas Claras mine clolomitic itabirite is found at the base of the sequence arrd is
overlain by quartz itabirite, while in the Pico mine quartz itabirite occurs from the base to the
top Layers of amphibolitic itabirite occur interlayerecl with quartz itabirite towarcl to the top of
the sequence at the Pico mine. This context allows us to suggest the presence of a lateral and
vertical faoies variation within the cauê Formation, going from clolomitio to quartz !o
amphibolitic itabi|ite as a result of variation in the seawater composition. We suggest that rìuring

the beginning of a transgressive cycle, whìle carbonatic secliments of dolomitic itabirite were
cleposited in a slightly shallowel site of Lhe basin (with a higher contribution of the marine
surface waters richer in tenigenous components and alcaline pH), cher.ty secliments of quartz
itabirite were deposited in a cleeper site (with very low content of terrigenous components and
acid pH). Graclual rncreasing water depths led to deposition of quartz itabirite in the Águas
Claras region. This occurred during the climax of the transgression. During the regression cycle,

the depositional conditions changed in the Águas claras region from those favouring quaÍz
itabirite to dolomite and marbles. In the Pico region, however, conclitions favonring deposition

of quartz itabirtte alternated to those favouring formation ofan itabirite containing layers rich i¡
terrigenous material now preservecl as amphibolitic itabitite. This would represeut shaly

sediments, with a much higher participation of terrigenous sediments carried by river waters.

CONCLUSIONS

Dolomitic ancl quartz itabirite are metamorphosed oxide 1àcies BfFs of thc Lake
Superior type of Paleoproterozoic agc, contcmporancous to the giant BlFs olthc l.Iamersley and
Transvaal basins. They consist of altemated millirnetric to decimctric bands of dolomite-rich and

hematite-rich, and cluartz-rich and hematite-rich, respectively. Both rocks have a very simple

chemical composition, with Fc2Or, CaO, MgO and LOi reprcsenting morc than 98% of the
average composition of dolomitic itabirite and FezO¡ ancl SiO2 constituting more than 98% of the

average composition of quartz itabirite. Itabirites were highly oxidized and pr.esent
Fe3*/(Fe2*+Fe3n) ratios highel than 0.98, much greater than the average ratio of othe¡
Paleoproterozoic BIFs.

Trace elements colìcentrations in itabirites are very low and range from <l0 pprn (Y,
Sc, Be, Cu, Ga, Ge, Rb, Nb, Mo, Ag, In, Sn, Cs, FIf, Tl, Pb, Bi, As, Cd, Th, U, Sb) ro

concentrations between 10 and 55 ppm (Ba, Sr, Zr, V, Ni, Zn, Co, Cr and IREE). Dolomitic and

quartz itabirite do not present major dif'l'erences in tmce element contents.

The FIREE enrichment pattem exhibited by both itabirites shows a modern seawater REE

signature overprinted by a hydrothemal pattem represented by positive EupAAS anomalies. A

marine sedimentary origin of the sediments of the dolomitic itabirite is reinforced by its REE

signatue, by the C and O isotopic composition, typical of marine carbonates, and by its Y/l,Io

ratios very similar to that of seawater. A strong coffelation between Alz0: and TiO2 (r>0.9)
indicates a minor terrigenous componcnt f'or the chemically precipitated, marine sediments of the

Cauê Formation.

The differences on the REE signatures ofthe itabirites suggest that they preoipitated from

aqueous solutions of different compositions, with the dolomitio itabirite receiving higher
contribution of marine surface waters laiden continental sediments and quartz itabirite of marine

bottom watels. Sea-level fluctuations caused by marine transgression-regressions are responsible

for changes in the aqueous solution composition. These changes ar.e expressed by dolomitic-,
quartz- and amphibolitic itabirites, which replesent lateral ancl vertical facies transitions of
carbonatic, cherty and shaly BIFs respectively.

ANEXO 3 - THE H¡GH.GRADE IRON ORES OF THE
Ácuas cLARAS MINE, euaonrÁTERo reRRírERo,

BRAZIL

Several majol iron deposits occur in Quadrilátero Fenífero (QF), Southeastetn Region of

Brazil, where metamorphosed and heterogeneously deformed bancled iton formation (BIF) of the

Cauô Formation, regionally called itabirites, were convertcd to high, (Fe>64%) and low-gmde

(30%<Fe<64%) hematite o¡es. Basecl on their mineralogical cornposition, three major types of

itabirites are described as occurring in the QF: quartz, clolomitic ancì amphibolitic. Unlike other

mines in thc QF, the Águas Claras mine contained mainly high-gracle ores, which occur within

dolomitic itabirite. Two distinct types of high-grade ore occurecl at the mine: soft and hard. The

soft ore was the most abundant and represented more than 85% of the total ore minecl until the

mine was depleted in 2002. The soft ore is highly porous, friable and partially preserves the

original structurc of the dolomitic itabirite protore, particularly meso- and microbanding, which

is characterized by lhe presence of massive and porous bancls within the ore. The hard ore is

dense, tough and compact. It occurs as small concordant lenses within the soft ore ancl within the

fiesh dolomitic itabirite. Soft and hard orcs consist essentially of hematite, occurling as martite,

anhedral to granular/tabula¡ her¡atite and, locally specularite. Gangue minerals are very rare,

consisting of dolomite, sericite, chlorite and apatite in the haril and soft ores, and Mn-oxicles ancl

femihyclrite in the soft ore, where they âre concentrated within the porous bands. Chemical
analyses showed that hard ancl soft orcs consist almost entirely ofFe2O3, with higher amount of
detrimental impurities, especially MnO, in the soft ore. Both hard and soft ores are very clepleted

in trace elements.

The high-grade ores have at least a dr.ral origin, involving hypogene and supergene
processes. The occurence of the hard massive high-grade ore within fresh dolomitic itabirite is a

good evidence of its hypogene origin. Despite the contention about the origin of thc clolomitic

itabirite (if this rock is a carbonatic facies of the Cauê Formation or a hematite-carbonate
precursor of the soft high-grade ore formed by hydrothermal alteration that removecl all the chert

from the BIF and replaced it with tlolomite), many features observed in the soft ore, such as: (l)
clear ilansition from the dolomitic itabirite into the soft ore; (2) disappearance of the soft ore

down dip, forming pinnacles; (3) pockets of clolornitic itabirite \¡/ithin the soft ore; (4) occunence

of slurnp folds in the soft ore, and Tertiary basins locally blanketing the orebody; (5)
petlographio eviclences of clolomite dissolution folning Mn-oxicles ancl fetrihyclrile (a metastable

iron lrydroxicle that tt'ansforms into hematite at temperatures as low as 4 "C, and (6) a similar

REEY pattern for lhe dolomitic itabirite and the soft ore, indicate that the soft high-gracle o¡e in

the Águas Claras mine was formecl by leaching of dolomite fiom the clolomitic itabirite by

meteoric water.

The original composition of tlìe itabiritic protore has a major role in the genesis ofhigh-

ancl low-gradc soft ores in the QF. Under the same weathering and structural collditions, tho

dolomitic itâbirite is more likely to form high-grade deposits than quartz itabirite, due to the

higher solubility of dolomite in rclation to quartz. Fielcl relationships at the Águas Claras ancl

Capão Xavier cleposits suggest that it is not possible to form huge soft high-gracle supergene
deposits from quartz itabirite, unless another control, such as imperrneable balriers, hacl played

an important role.

INTRODUCTION

The Aguas Claras iron-ore rnine is located in the Quaclrilátero Ferrífero (QF),
Southeastem Region of Brazil, state of Minas Gerais (Fig- l). Open-pit mining a[ Águas Claras

commenced in 1973 and, by 2002, when thc mine .¡/as closecl, approximately 288 Mt of high-
grade iron ore (average Fe>68%) had been mined on the crest and along the slopes of a segment

of the Sema do Curual. About 88 Mt of high-grade it'on ote remainecl, but economic and
environmental restrictions prevented mining from continuing. The high quality of its products

and the large tonnage obtainecl placcd thc Aguas Clalas rninc among the ¡nosl. irnportant iron

mines during that time.

Despite its world-class category and the significant amount of data gatherecl on the mine

since mining began in 1973, very little geological information on the mine is available in
publishecl literature (Gomes 1986; Viel et al. 1987; Flackspacher 1979). Recently, Spier et al.

(2003) clescribed the geology ofthe Águas Claras ancì Pico iron mines ancl presented data for the

main chemical constituents of the iron ore at those mines. This study complements that previous

work, presenting a detailed study on the mineralogy and geochemistry of the iron ores of the

Águas Clalas mine and aims at contributing to the cliscussion on their genesis.



166

The rnajority of the iron orebodies at the QF afe hostecl in itabirites (oxklized,
metamorphosed and heterogeneously deformed BIFs) of the Cauô Formation, Itabira Group.

Itabirites of the Cauô Formation arc vely similar in lithology to most major oxide-facies BIFs

known worlclwide (Dorr II 1969). Based on their mineralogioal oornposition, three major types of

itabirites are described as occurring in the QF: quartz, ilolomitic and amphibolitic.

Unlike other mines of the QF, the Águas Claras mine containeci rnainly high-gracle ore (Fe

>64%) hostccl within clolomitic itabirite. Although quartz and dolomitic itabirite crop out at the

mine, the high-grade ore was developeci mainly within lhe latter. Two distinct types of high-

grade ore occur at the mine: soft ancl harcl. The soft ore was the most abunclant and teprescntecl

morc than 85% of the total ore minecl. It was consideretl by Spier et al. (2003) as of supergerre

origin, whereas the hard ore was considered by the same authors as of hypogene origin, because

it occurs within fresh dolomitic ilabirite. Some features of the soft ore such as the great depth of

mineralization and the lack of goethite, otherwise, could suggest [hat this type of ore is also of

hypogene origin.

The genesis of the high-grade (Fe> 64%) and low-grade (30%<Fe <64Yo) ron ores within

the Cauê Formation has been the object of clebate since the beginning of the 20tl' century ancl

continues to be the focus of studies by several reseatchers (e.g. Cabral et al. 2003; Dolr II 1964;
Dorr II 1965; Guilcl 1953; Harder ancl Chamberlarn l9l5; Park 1959; Ramanaidou 1989;
Ramanaidou et aI. 1996; Rosière and Rios 2004). Most studies are concentratecl in ores
originating from quartz itabirite, the most common type of itabirite in the region, probably

because dolomitic itabirite is more restricted to and concenttated along the Serra do Curral (Fig.

l). The genesis of the iron ore originating from dolomitic itabirite in the QF has never been
studiecl in detail, and several questions remain open, Why were the high-gracle ores at the Águas

Claras mine formed mainly from dolomitic itabirite and not from quartz itabirite? Why were the

high-grade ores formed from quartz itabirite limited to few meters below the topographic

surface? Were the hard and soft ores formed during thc same event? Coulcl the soft ore be

procluced only by weatl.reriug? Are new minerals formed during leaching of the carbonates? Thls

paper address lhose qneslions, in oldcr to conttibutc for cliscussions about the genesis of the iron

ore in the QF and worldwide .

Paleoproterozoic Minas Supergroup metasseclimelrta y rocks forrn lhe mounlain ranges of

the QF, whereas the lowlands are occupied by Archean granite-glleiss basement rocks and the

Rio das Velhas Greenstone Belt sequence (Fig. l). The giant iron ore tleposits of the QF are

hosted in the platformal sediments of the Minas Supergroup and consist of three metamorphic

sequences (Don 1969). The lowest unit is the Caraça Group, which contains clastic sedirnents.

The middle Itabira Group cornprises itabirites with minor dolomite ancl phyllite of the Cauê

Formation and carbonate rocks ofthe Gandarela Formation. ltabirites gracle upward to clolomites

ancl dolomitic/manganiferous itabirites of the 2.4 Ga Ganclarela Formatlon (Babinski et al. 1995).

northeast-southwest trending -100 krn-long lidge that limits the nortlìwest edge of tlìe QF (Fig.

1). Units of the Minas Supergroup crop out along most of its extension as an invelted scqueÌtcc

without repetition. Irr the northern segment of the Serra do Culral, the rocks are strained,
sittistrally rotated fiom their original position, and becls are overturned (Chernale Jr. el al. 1994).

The Dolomitic Itabirite (Protore)

The dolornitic itabirite occu¡s as a continuous 150 to 400 m thick layer and represents the

protore of the soft iron ore. Its petrography and geochernistry were describecl in detail by Spier et

al. (2005a) and will be briefly addressed herein. Bancling of crn-sized iron-rich alìd dolomite-ricll

bands is the most conspicuous macroscopic features of the dolomitic itabirite, charactorizing the

mesobanding defined by Trendall and Blockley (1970) fol BIFs of the Ilamersley basin. At thc

base of the sequence, the dolomitic bands are thicker and predornûrate over the irou-rich tratids.

The forrner display colol shades ranging frorn deep red to pink and have a cm- to dm-sized

thickness, while the latler are gray and range frorn less tl'ran one rnillimeter to 3 cm thick. At

about 50 m up on the sequelrce, the thickness ofthe dolomitic band is reduced thus giving origin

to the typical dolornitic itabirite, where -lcrn bands of dolomite altornâte with hematitic bands
(Fig. 3a) throughout -250 rneters of itabilite. To fhe top, hematitic bands gradually disappear,

and a fenuginous dololnite predominates. A mm-sized banding of iron-rich alid dolornite-ricli

larninaes (rniclobanding) also occurs, especially within dolornite-rich nlesobands (Fig. 4a).

The cal'bonate bands of dolomitic itabirite cousist of very fine graiued sparry dolomite and

lìematite with glain size ranging ftom 5-30 pLm (the average being 20 Fm, Fig. 4b). The volurne

of lrernatite within the oarboltate bauds is highly variable (5% to 50% frorn band to band).

lìernatite occurs mainly as individual crystals of tabulal shape irrtergrown with dolornite, or else

(specularite) occurs jn shear planes, sunouncling crystals of tabular/glanular hematite (Fig. ad).

carbonate bands account for the characteristic deep red color of tl'ìese bands.

The iron-rich bands contain hernatite (>80%), interstitial carbonates and pores (Fig. ae-f).

The average hematite grain size is similar to that of the dolomitic bands (- 20 prm) ranging from

5-30 pm. Hematite occurs mainly as tabular and granular crystals growirrg over martite (hematite

pseudomorphous after magnetite), forming a dense network. Hematite also occurs locally as

specularite. Traces of magnetite are observed in the nuclei of some hematite crystals, especially

in the coarser iron-rich bands.

Accessory minerals are also present irr the dolomitic itabirite. Talc occurs intergrown

with dolomite (Fig. 49) and associated with chlo¡ite in thin veins. Apatite can be found forming

monomineral layers (<l mrn) or as isolated euhedral crystals (4-10 pm) intergrown with or
included in hematite and dolomite crystals (Fig. ah). Chlorite occurs along veins and shear
planes.

The lron Ore

The Águas Claras orebody comprises soft and hard high-grade ores (Fig. 3b-c). The

orebody is a bedding-concordant, 2,500 m long, roughly tabular-shaped lens with a maximum

thickness of 300 m and formed essentially by soft ores (Fig. 2b). The hard ores generally occur

within the soft ores as minor lenses concordant to the bedding. The depth of the orebody is
variable, extending to over 400 rn below the surface at the center of the pit bottom and then
grading into the parental fresh dolomitic itabirite deeper down (Fig. 2a).In this contact region, it

is very common to find the presence of pinnacles of fresh dolomitic itabirite surrounded by the

soft ore (Fig. 3d). Higher levels of contaminants in the iron ore, especially apatite, occur in this

zone. Dip and strike of the orebody are conformable with regional trends, i.e., strike is northeast-

southwest, dip is 65" to 80' SE.

The soft ore is gray, friable and has a laminated appearance. It preserues partially the
original structure of the protore, particularly meso- and microbanding, which is characterizedby

the presence of massive and porous bands within the ore, parallel to the banding of the itabirite

(Figs. 3b, 5a-f). Adjacent bands are rarely of similar thickness. Field relationships show that
iron-rich bands of dolomitic itabirite grade into the massive bands in the iron ore, while
dolomite-rich bands grade into the porous bands. Even massive bands are porous, but they have

less than 30 percent of pore space, and individual pores are isolated in massive hematite.
Generally massive bands are broken and disrupted while porous bands show free aggregates of
hematite between pores (Fig. 5f-g). Kink-bands (not present in the protore) are locally observed.

The harcl orc is clense, tough, compact, dark bluish gray and has a dull to metallic lusteÍ

SAMPLING AND ANALYTICAL PROCEDURES

Eighty-six samples representing the harcl and soft ores were collectecl from diamond drill

cores and outcrops along the benches of the mine. Appendix I presents the local coordinate of
each sample and the respective analytical proceduTe followetl. Detailed sampling was carrie<l out

in the zone of contact with the protore, in order to access the transition from the dolomitic
itabirite to the iron oro. All samples were impregnatecl with epoxy resin and polishecl for
petrographic analyses puryoses. Samples ofeach type ofore were submitted to scanning electron

microscopy (SEM). The porous band of the sofl ore was examined by transmission electlon

microscopy (TEM). SEM analyses were caruied out at the laboratories of the Geoscience
lnstitute of the University of São Paulo, Brazil, and at the Center for Microscopy ancl
Microanalyses of the University of Queenslancl, Australia, where TEM aualyses were also
camiecl out,

Eight ore samples were selected for Mössbauer spectroscopy (MS), consisting offonr soft

ore ancl four hard ore. For each sample of soft ore, the massive band (samples MAC-1264 to

MAC-1294) was carefully separated from the porous band (samples MAC-1268 to MAC-

129B). For the hard ore, samples of sub{ypes massive (MAC-97), banded (MAC-67 and MAC-

105), and schistose (MAC-68) orcs welc selected. Besides the iron ore samples, two samples

(MAC-96 and MAC-100) of the fresh clolomitic bancl of the dolomitic itabirite were examined



175

by MS. Transmission sTFe Mössbauer spectra at 300 K were obtainecl on a constant acceleration

spectrometer using a sTColRh source at the Laboratoty of Applied Physios of the Nuclear
Technology Developmeut Centet (CDTN) in Belo I'Iorizonte. Mössbauel spectra of t'our samples

(MAC97, MACl27A, MACl2TB and MACl00) were also recordecl at 50 K. A least-square fit-
program was employecl to calculate the spectral hyperlìne parametels. All samples stuclied by
MS were char¿cterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) at the hrstitute of Physics of the Fecleral

University of Minas Gerais (UFMG). Unit cell parameters of hematite were cletermined using the

Rietveld refiuement for samples MAC67, MAC 97 and MAC 127 A and B.

Eighty-six samples of the iron ore were analyzed by ICP for major and some tracc
elements (Ba, V, Ni, Cu and Zn) at the chemical laboratory of MBR. From the total number of

samples, 48 were selected for analyses of major. traoe and rare earth elements (REE) at the

Activation Laboratories - ACT'LABS in Canacla. All samples were prepared for analysis by
grinding in a tungston carbide vessel. Since this method causes contamination by W, Co ancl Ta,

concentrations of these elements are not reported. In ACTLABS, major and trace elements were

determined by ICP^CP-MS afl:er the opening of the sample with a lithium tetraborate/metaborate

fusion. Base metals were cletermined by ICP-MS/INAA after total cligestion by acid attack.

Fenous iron was dotermined at the laboratories of MBR by potassium dichromate titration. REE

data on the Post Archean Australian Shale (PAAS) obtained by Mclennan (1989) were used as

normalization values. We present REE patterns with Y inserted between Dy ancl FIo according to

its ionic radius. The reason why we included Y in the lanthanides lies in the value of
comparative studies of the behavior of Y and REE in aqueous solutions and their precipitates
(Bau and Dulski 1996). In our case, the precipitates vr'el'e the original sediments of the dolomitic

itabirite. The Eu anomaly is clefined quantitatively as:

where Eu* is the hypothetical concentration of Eu. The anomâlies of Ce and Y were similarly

MAC-100, as compared to the doublet in sample MAC-96, can be interpleted as a higher amount

of dolomite in sample MAC-100. The relative abunclance of these minerals is expressed by the

subspectral areas of hematile and siclerite in the MS of the samples MAC-100 ancl MAC-96

Soft lron Ores

Mineralogy and Petrology

The soft ore consists of altelnated mm- to cm-sized massive and highly porous ban<ls, both rich

in iron oxides (Figs. 5 and 7). The forrnel conesponds to the iron-rich bands of the dolornitic

itabirite while the lattet coffesponds to the dolomite-rich bands. The soft ore as a whole is highly

porous, with intergranular porosity visually estimated in thin sections ar 35 - 45yo (Fig. 5b).
I-iematite is the major iron oxi<le in both bands, occuning as martite, anhedral to granular/tabular

180

obtained close to contacts with both the ptotore ancl the phyllite. They are also rnore flequent

'¡/ithin the porous bands ancl consist of apatite, talc, chlorite ancl Mn-oxides (Figs. 8a-f). Apatite

is tnore ftequeut iu samples fiom the lower levels of lhe nrino, especially from the bottom pit,

whete the pinnacles occur'.

The massive barrds ofthe soft ore generally show a granoblastic fabric and consist offine

granular ancl tabular hematite (5-20 pm), forming a clense paokage (Figs. 7e-g). The porous

bands lrave variable porosity, visually estimated at 30 - 60Yo. They consist of aggregates ranging
from 50 pm to l0 rnm of granular and tabular hematite crystals (up to 60%) and/or of in<lividual

clystals of tabular hematite langing from l0 to 30 ¡rm (Figs. 7e ancl h). Locally, it is possible to

obserue the development of tabular and granular hematite growing over coarser martite crystâls

(-50 pm) and the desaggregation of these crystals, causing the release of the finel. tabular
hematite (Fig. 7 g-h). Flernatite crystals are surrounded by a brownish residue of poorly
crystalline fenihyclrite (Figs. 7 a-d). Ferrihydrite is produced during the dissolution of dolornite,

a process which is clearly represented in thin sections of partially weathered tlolomitic itabirite,

where it forms a brownish resiclue.

SEM observations of the<0.15 mm size fraction of some samples of the soft ore have
also shown a few small particles of Mn oxides besides hematite (Fig. 8d). TEM analyses confirm

the prcsence of these Mn oxides within the porous bands (Figs. 9a-c). They occur as very small

particles (-100 1m) mixed with the iron oxicles.

In samples collectecl from the zone of contact with the protore, it is possible to observe
remnants of dolomite intergrown with hematite and gangue minerals. Apatite is very well
preserved in this zone, forming thin laminae parallel to the banding or occurling as isolated
etrhedral crystals (Figs. 8a-c). Talc ancl chlorite are also observed as isolated crystals or fornring

mm-sized aggregates (Figs. 8 e-f).

XRD and Mössbauer Analyses

XRD analyses of the massive bands of the soft ore (Samples MAC-1264 to MAC-1294)
revealed only the presence of hematite (Fig.l0). The sharp XRD peaks suggest high crystallinity.

The 300 K Mössbauer spectra fitted perfectly with hematite, with a hyperfine field of about 52 T,

isomer shift of about 0.37 mm,/s, and a quadrupole shift of about -{.15 mm/s (Table l). All the
spectra are very similar, consisting of 100% of hematite and are represented by the spectnrm
recorded at 300 and 50 K of sample MAC127A in Fig. I I a and b. The MS of the massive bands

have also revealed the presence of the Morin transition (a transition from an antiferrolnagnetic to

a weakly ferromagnetic state, at about 265 K). This transition is very sensil.ive to
microcrystalline effects, lattice imperfections and impurities. Its observâtion in the studíecl
samples indicates a very pure composition of hematite and crystallites larger than 20 r1m. The

unit cell parameters obtainecl for the hematite in the sarnple MACl2l A (Tab\e 2), which are very

similar to those of the refelence cell of hematite.

Ore Type

XRD analyses of the porous bands of the soft ore (Samples MAC-1268 to MAC-1298)

showed the presence of only hematite (Fig. l0). Thus, the observecl diffused, limonitic, brownish

material in the porons bands must be amorphous.

The Mössbauer spectra at 300 K of the porous bands are represented by sample
MAC l2TB in Fig. I l c. There is a major sextet corresponding to a hyperfine held of about 52 T

and a quaclrupole shift of about -0. l3 mm/s, parameters that fit pert'ectly \¡/ith those of hematite.

MS at 50 K of this sample conftrms the ptesence of hematite, characterized by an isomer shift of

0.48 mr¡/s ancl a hyperfine fielcl of 54.9 T (Table l, Fig. lld). The hyperfine parametels of
hematite ìn tlie porous bancls are quite similar to those observed for this mineral in thc dolornitic

itabirite ancl massive bancls of the sofì ore (Tablc l). Thc unit cell parameters of hematite in
sample MACI2TB are also very similar not only to those of hematite in the massive bancls of the

soft ancl hard ores but also to the reference cell parameters of hematite (Table 2).

An ill defined doublet superimposed to the hematite sextet is present in all spectra of the
porous band (Fig. 1le). This doublet can be ascribed to the lirnonitrc, brownish material which is

the resiclue of the clissolution of dolomite. The isomer shift (0.34 - 0.35 mm/s) and the
qnaclrupole splitting (0.68 mm/s) at 300 K of these samples match well with those of ferrihyclrite

(Couell and Schwertmann 1996, p. 149). In the MS at 50 K of sample MACI2TB (which
presents the best dofinod doublet at 300 K), the cloublet is still present, with an isomer sliifl of

0.42 mrn/s antl a quadtupole splittir.rg of 0,76 mm/s. These values are compatible with those

found by Childs and Baker-Shelman (1984) for synthetic fenihyclrite at 77 K. The abscnce of a
sextet at 50 K inclicates the poor crystallinity of this mineral, given that magnetic orclering is
strongly depenclent on crystallinity (Cornell and Schwertmann 1996). The low crystallinity of

ferrihydrite, on the other hand, explains its absence from the XRD pattems. Mössbaue¡
spectrosoopy confirms, therefore, that the brownish material observed by optical petrography in

the residue of the dolornite clissolution is ferrihydrite. Based on the valucs of the ¡elative
subspectral arcas, the abundances of hematite and fen ihyclrite were estimated. It is seen from
Table I that fenihydrite is a suborclinate componelìt in the soft ore.

Although rernnants of magnetite were locally recognized within hematite crystals by
petrographic observation, this mineral was not detectod in the MS. The same occurred with

siderite (present in dolomite) in sample MAC-67. The appearance of six lines in the MS and the

hyperfine paÍameters of the harcl ore samples are due to the presence of the single iron-bearing

phase, i.e., hematite. fhe absence of magnetite lines is related to the very high degree of
martitization (oxidation).

Hard lron Ores

Miner alogy an d P etro lo gy

Petrographic and SEM observations of the massive, bandecl ancl schistose hard iron ores

have shown a very simple mineralogical composition. The iron oxide rnineralogy is the same of

l.he soft ole. Gangue minerals are very rare, consisting of clolomite and, locally, apatite and talc.

In weathered liard ores gangue minerals are generally absent, creating a macropolosity. ln highly

fi'acturecl oreboclies, goethite and kaolinite occLu as thin fihns on the surface of the ore, oven at

deeper depths (Fig. 3!. There is no difference itr the mineralogical composition of the three
major sub-types ofhard ore, except in fabric ancl porosity.

Massive halcl ore consists of tabular and granular hematite (up to 80%) ranging in sizc

from 5 to 30 prn (average of20 pm), forming a granoblastic fabrio (Figs. l6a-d). Martite (up to

50 pm) with remnants of magnetite occur between her¡atite crystals (Fig. l6e). Locally, it is

possible to observe the growth of hematite over rnartite crystals. Porosity in hard massive ores

mày vàry from approximately 5 to 20o/o, and pore size from <I to 50 Frm. Fresh ores exhibit the

lowest porosity of all hard ores, around 3ol0, increasing up to 20%o in weathered samples.

Banded h¿rcl ore consists of altemated massive and porous layers (Fig. 16fl. Tabular and

granular hematite are the main iron oxicles (up to 70%) with grain size ranging florn 5 - 20 pm

(Fig. 169). They grow over martite or occur as isolated crystals. Martite with remnants of

magnetite may occur as indiviclual crystals ranging from 30 - 50 ¡Lrn or forming clense
aggregates, representing up to 5% of the volume. Speculalite (up to 5%) occurs locally, aloÌìg

shear planes parallel to or cutting the banding ancl defining a cliscontinuously developed
foliaiion. Porosity is highly variable in bancled iron ores, reaching up to 30% of the volume.

Schistose hard ore prescnts a lepidoblastic fabric which is composecl mainly of tabular

hematite and specularite (up to 70%) wrapping around porphyroclastic agglegates of tabular ancl

granular hematite (up [o 50%, Fig. l6h). Porosity in the schistose ore ranges from 5 to 20%.

DISCUSSION

Comparison between hard and soft ores

The major difference between hard ancl soft ores, besicles the mechanical strength, is their

mode of occurrence. The soft ore forms a large, km-sized lens, which grades laterally and

vertically to the parent clolomitic itabirite. Fielcl relationships show the transition from the

dolomite-rich bands of the dolomitic itabirite into the porons band ofthe soft ore. This transition

is marked by dissolution of the dolomite-rich bancls, thereby producing a highly porous residue

which is very rich in the hematite originally present within the clolornite-rich banrls. The i¡on-

rich bands of the clolomitic ifabilite are little affectecl by this dissolution process and forrn the

massive band of the soft ore. The hard ore occrrs as discontinuous lenses within the fiesh

clolomitic itabirite ancl sofl ore. These fielcl relationships indicate that the hard iron ore was

formed earlier than the soft iron ore. lt also suggests rhat the harcl iron ore, like the iron-rich
bands of the dolomitic itabirite, was little affectecl by the dissolution plocess, remaining as lenses

within the soft ore.

The next important clifference betwcen harcl ancl soft ores is potosity, which control their

mechanical strength. Two types of porosity are observecl in the iron ores: macro and
microporosity. The former is related to the spaces between the iron oxides crystals and
constitutes the major factor affccting the hardness of ths ol'e. It is formed by leaching of the
gangue minerals, probably by weathering solutions (see text below). The latter is relatecl to the

presence of pores within the iron oxide crystals which are fonnecl<luring the oxiclation of



201

magnetite into martite. The hard iron ore is much less porous than the soft ore, which accounts

for its harclness. The soft ores are highly porous and, consequently, soft. A more frequent
prosence of carbonate in tl,e rock plior to dissolution results in higher polosity ancl higher

friability. Variations in the porosity and fabric of the harcl ore ale responsible fbr the different:

sub-types observed,

'Ihe major difference in the mineralogy of the hard and soft ores is the slightly higher

amount of gangue minerals in the latter. The gangue minerals are also different in each type of

ore. Although both ores have a very low amount ofdehimental impurities, these are concentrated

in the soft ore. Dolomite, sericite, chlof ite and apatite are the most common gangue minerals,

both in the hard and in tl.re soft ore. Mn-oxides and ferrihydrite are concentrated withjn the

porous bancls of the soft ore and are absent Íïom the lìard ore, I'Iigher âmornts of gangue

minerals, €specially apatite and Mu-oxides, occur in deeper clepths close to the contact of the soft

ore with the protore. This zone lias lowel permeability, thus favoring the residual concentrâtion

of apatite (whioh is less soluble than dolomite) together with Mn-oxicles produced duting
dolomite dissolution (see discussion below).

The iron oxide mineralogy of the hard ancl soft ores is exactly the same, as demonstrated

by optical microscopy, SEM, XRD and MS, and consists esscntially of granular and tabular

hematite- This mineral occurs growing over martite crystals or as individual crystals forming the

densc aggregates of a granoblastic fabric both in hard ores ancl in massive bands of soft ore.

Hemâtite has the same Mössbauer hyperftne parameters both in fresh dolomitic bands and in

hard and soft ores (Table l). The Mössbauer spectra of all samples can be well fitted with only

one sextet. The value of the hyperfine fìekt (51.9 T) correspotrds to that ofpure, well-crystallize<l

hematìte, inclicating that it cloes not contain cletectable amounts of Al (Fysh and Clark 1982;
Murad and Schwerlmann 1986). This conclusion is also supported by the hematite unit cell

parametors obtained fiom the Rietveld analyses, which point to the purity of this mineral. Tlie

isomer sl.rift of all the sextets shows that iron is exolusively ptesent in the Fe3r state. Although

remnants of magnetite are locally observed either in harcl or in solì ores, this mineral was

submitted to a v€ry high degree of martitization. This phenomenon occuued prior to the genesis

of the soft ore, consrdering the identical hyperfine parameters of the ilon oxi<les observecl in the

dolomitic itabirite þrotore) and in the soft ore. This is further supported by chemical analyses of

the clolomitic itabirite, which reveal Fe3*/1Fe3 
*+Fe2') 

raiios close to one (Spier et al. 2005a).

The geochemistry of the hald and soft orcs reflects a higher amount of detrimental

imptrrities in the soft ore (Table 3,Frg. l2a), especialty MnO, whose average coutent in tl'ìe soft



202

ore is 33 times higher than ir, the hard ore. Other majol constituents like AlzO¡ (2.0x), SiO2

(1.6x), TiO2 (1.7x) and P2O5 (1.4x), together with LOI (1.6x), also show the increase of
irnpurities in lhe soft ore. Both hard ancl soft ores are very tlepletecl in tlace elements (Table 3,

Fig. l3a), excepted for Ba (2.5x), Sr (3.0x), Y (3.1x), V (1.7x), Th (1.8x) antì )REE (3.2x),

whích show higher concentrations in the soft ore than in the har<l ore. Anothet important

difference between ha¡d ancl so{l ores is their respective REEY contents and fractionation
pattems. While the soft ore preserves the REEY pattern of the dolomitic itabìrite (Fig. 14c), even

when the cotrespondent iron-rich/massive bancls and dolomite-rich/porous bands are considcred

separately (Fig. lad), the hard ore presents a distinct REEY pattern, characterized by depletion in

heavy REE relative to micldle REE.

Formation of Tabular and Granular Hematite Within Martite Crystals

Even though the question of which primary iron minerals precipitatecl on the sea floor

during the growth of the BIFs remains a source of debate in literature, there is a general
consensus that they were mostly ferric (hydr)oxides (goethite and/or hematite) (Ohmoto 2003;

Trendall 2002). A later process during diagenesis and/or metamorphism transformed the feric

(hydr)oxides into magnetite (Monis 1993; Perry Jr. et aL 1973; Walker 1984; Walker 1987).

Magnetite is found ubiquitously in BIFs throughout the world- In the QF region, it is intelpreted

to be the oldest iron oxide of the iron mineral assemblage (Rosière l98l; Rosière ancl Chemale
Jr. 2000; Rosière et al. 1993; Rosière ancl Rios 2004). The coarse crystals of magnetite in BIFs of

the QF sr.rggest that they were folmed during diagenesis and/or metamorphism, considering that

primary iron precipitates must have been coloidal.

Magnetite was almost totally oxidized and recrystallized during the metamorphic and

tectonic evolution of the BIFs of the Cauê Formation (Rosière l98l). The transition from
magnetite to martite is less well preserved in the Águas Clalas rocks, but it is well docurnented

in other sites in the QF. The most impressive fèature observecl in this study is the development of

hematite within mattite crystals, 'Ihe petrographìcal analyses indicate that recrystallization of

martite during metamoryhism and deformation (probably during the Transamazonian
Orogenesis) was responsible for the generation ofthe hematite crystals within martite, accorcling

to the mechanisms proposed by llackspacher et al. (2001), Lagoeiro (1998), Rosière (1981) and

Rosière et al. (2001). The degree of recrystallization, ho.rr'ever, was not uniform, making it
possible to observe the several steps of transformation fiom ma1tite to tabular hematite, passing

through anl,edral and granular hematite (Fig. 19). These hematite crystals coresponcl to the



Hematite II of Rosière and Rios (2004) and are conspicuously observed in our samples. The
passage from martite to tabular hematite in Águas Claras is an intermediate step in the
development of specularite, which occurs in high strained zones of the QF, according to Rosière

and Rios (2004).Its register in our samples offers further support to the model of those authors.

Comparisons with othcr iron mines on the western s¡de of the Quadrilátero Ferrífero

ln ortler to cont¡ibute to tl.re discussion on the genesis of iron ores at the Águas Claras

tnine, we will give a brief presentation of ano[her Lwo, giant, world-class iron rnines on the

western side of the QF: Capão Xaviel and Tamanduá. Capão Xavier is located on the westerx

side ancl Tamanduá on the eastem side of thc Moeda Syncline (Fig l). Geological sections of
each mine are presented in Figure 20.

Capão Xavier Mine
"lhe Capão Xavier olebocly is quite similar to the Águas Claras orebody. lt consists of a

large, concordant lense ofhigh-grade ore hosted within dolorniric itabirite. Soft high-grade orc is

largely predominalìt and represent 82% of the 233 Mt of geological resources. Flard high-grade

ote occurs as local, metric lenses within the soft ore. Low-grade ores (30%<Fe<64%), fbnned

from quartz itabirite, are subordinated within the pit of the mine, but wirlespread outside of this

limit, having not been considered in the geological resources mentionecl above. Differently from

the Águas Claras ancl Tamanduá, thc Capão Xavier's whole structure, and particularly the BIFs,

dips gently, with a maximum angle of45 degrees to the northeast. The weathering front varies in

depth from a few meters in the quartz itabirite to more than 300 m in the dolomitic itabirite. Soft

high-gracle ore reaches a maximum depth of 280 m. A thick (5 - 50 m) transition zone,
characterized by high contents of AlzO¡ and Mn, is usually observed in the contact of the soft ore

with the dolomitic itabirite. The greater thickness of the transition zone can be attributed to the

gentle dip of the dolomitic itabirite in the Capão Xavier orebocly, which would have hampered

the action of the clownward weathering solutions through the banding.

Weathering of the quartz itabiritc at the Capão Xavier deposit pro<lucec1 a goethitic rock,

called limonitic itabirite. This rock consists essentially of hematite ancl goethite with
subordinated quartz. The iron content of limonitic itabirite decreases in depth into the iron-rich

Tanaruluá Mine

The Tarnanduá deposit is locatecl in the Tamanduá Synclirre, which is a second-orcler folcl

of the Moecla Syncline (Fig. l). The orebody, hosted within quartz itabirite, strikes NWSE, sub-
parallel to the eastern limb of the Moecla Syncline (Fig. l). In this area, the Cauê Formation is
2,000 m thick, clue fo folcling. The orebody is transversally cut by tv/o strike-slip faults hosting

important dykes mostly of basic composition, which limits [he orebody and divides ìt in tlrree

clomains. The richest ancl thickest high-grade bodies ale located in the central domâin, \¡/ithin a

syncline, in contact witli phyllite (Fig. 20b).

The Tamanduá orebocly is composed of soft, high-grade ote, with lenscs ofhard ore, and

low-grade ore. Sof't and hard ores represent 80% ancl 20o%, respectively, of the 291 Mt of hìgh-

grade resources. Low-grade ore comprises 480 Mt of i¡on-rich itabirìte, soft-itabirite and
limonitic itabirite. The orebody is approximately 2.800 m long and 400 m thick.

High-graile ores occur mainly within the syncline, in contact with the phyllite, where

lenses ofhard ore, strongly fractured, occur involvecl by medium and sofl high-grade ores and by

iron-rich/soft itabirites, forming a complex auangement (Fig.20b). The soft ore reaches more

than 500 m dcpth in this sitc. The harcl orebodies may be rnassive ol porolrs, ancl their shapes

central domain of the Tamanduá deposit and is related to oblique shear zones. Subordinated

and the low-grade ore is gtadual when it occurs close to the topographic surface and sharp when

it occurs in greater depths (Fig. 21c).

Ore Gencsis

Most of the iron ore proclucecl in the world results from the enrichment of precambrian

BIFs, but the processes responsible for this enrichment are still unclear and constitute a souroe of

debates in the literature (Dalstra et al. 2002; Kneeshaw and Keped 2002; Moris 2002a-c). Two

end-member genetic rnoclels have been proposed: supergene velsus hydrothermal enrìchment of

a BIF protore. Supergene iron ores are the most abundant type of iron ores either in the QF,
where tlrey represent rnore than 70n/o of nhe 27 Gt of geological tesources (Gomes, 1986; MBR

and CVRD, internal reports), or in the Westem Australian Hamersley basin, where the martite-

goethite ores account for some 90% or more ofthe BlF-derivecl enrichment ores (Harmsworth et

a1., 1990; Monis, 2002c). Supergene ore arises by the selective leaching of gangue minerals

from the BIF by ground water and the residual accumulation of the iron oxicles. Hypogene ores

form the richest iron orebodies. Their genesis is ascribed to the interaction of the BlFs with a

hydrothermal fluid, which dissolved chert (quartz), leaving porcs spaces, that were or not filled

by a new generation of iron oxides.

The oocurrence of the har<l, massive high-gracle ores within lì'esh itabirite at the Águas

Claras and Tamancluá mines is a sh'ong eviclence of their hypogene origin. This type of ore is

similar to those described, for instance, by Taylol et al. (2001), Beukes et al. (2002) and Guedes

et al. (2002), .,vhich are interpreted as formed by hyclrothermal fluids. However, at Águas

Claras, petrographic and mineralogic data provide little information regarding the hypogene

solutions and their precipitates. Flematite has a very simple chemical composition and a wide

stability field, thereby restricting its use in metallogenetic stuclies. Additional difficulties, such as

superimpositiotr of tectonic events and weathcring, turn the undol'stancling of thc genesis of this



209

hard ore into a difficr.rlt pr.rzzle. Nevertheless, there are some new insights into this subject. They

atose from the infrared microscopic analysis and t'luicl inclusion studies in hematite carriecl out

by Rosière and Rios (2004). These authors suggest that the lormation of the hald massive hrgh-

grade oreboclies occulrecl during the Transamazonian evont (ca. 2.1-2.0 Ga; Alkmim ancl

Marshak, 1998) and developed in two stages. ht the first, contractional stage of the
Transamazonian orogeny a pewasive magnetite mineralization occurred in the BIF by reduced

motamorphic fluicls- Hematite mineralization occuüed during the collapse stage of the orogeny,

coincident with lhe uplift of the basement, intrusion of granitic plntons and extension of the

crust, and involved low-temperature meteoric fluids moving clownwards from the surface along

normal faults and fractures. These flr¡ids wele also responsible for the oxiclation of magnetite

(martitization), and were concentrated only at sites of great permeability such as folcl hinges,

forming the hard, massive high-grade orebodies.

Hârdel to explain is the origin of the giant, soft high-grade oreboclies, such as the Águas

Claras orebocly. Tlle general lack of typical secondary minerals as goethite in the ore coulcl

indicate leaching of gangue minerals from BIFs by hypogene solutions, but in some cases, other

argumenl.s point fo a supergene origin.

The soft ore al the QF orebodies is generally interlayered with or surounding the hard,

massive, hypogene ores. This relation led many authors (Beukes et a|.2002; Dorr II 1965; Guild
1953; Rosière and Rios 2004) to propose its hypogene-supergene modified origin. llypogene-

supergene modified models comprise an initial, hypogene stage, with either leaching of all the

chert from the BIF protore leaving pore spaces (Dorr iI 1965; Guilct 1953) or with metasomatic
replacement of those minerals by carbonates, followcd by a snpergene stage that leached the

hytlrotermal minerals formed in the previous stage (Beukes el al.2002). Águas Claras mine was

mentioned by Beukes et al. (2002) as the best example, one where the dolomitic itabirite
"obviously developed from the replacement of chert bands in iron-formation". Flypogene-
supsrgene modified genetic models were also proposecl for the genesis of the high-grade
lrematite ores at the flamersley ancl Carajás Provinces (Beukes et al. 2002; Guedes et al.2002;

Taylor et al. 2001; Thorne et al. 2004; Webb et al. 2004). Recently, Dalstra and Guedes (2004)

suggested that magnetite-carbonate-amphibole, mâgnetite-carbonate or hematite-carbonate
ptecursors were essential in the formation of high-grade hematite ores worldwicle. Their
proposed genetic model involves early hyclrothermal depletion ofsilica in the host iron formation

and introduction of Ca-Fe-Mg-carbonates, followed by supergene leaching of the carbonates,

long after they ale formed, to create the high-glade hematite ores.



210

'I'he use of hypogene- supergene models proposecl by Beukes et al. (2002), Dalst¡a ancl

Guedes (2004) ancl Rosière and Rios (2004) to explain the genesis of the soft high-grade ore at

the Águas Claras ancl Capão Xavier mines presenls some issues Lhat ueecl [o be addressecl. One

of them concems the origin of the dolomitic itabifite. Beukes et al. (2002) considerecl the
clolomitic itabirite of the Águas Claras mine as a procluct of dolomitisation of a cherr BIF by

hydrothermal solutions. Flowever, they did not take into âccorult the regional geological setting.

The Car.rê Fortnation (inclucling quartz and dolomitic itabirite) gracles upward into the clolomite

of the Gandarela Formation, a typical marine sequence hosting stromatolites. The contacts of the

Cauô antl the Ganclarela Formations are laterally and vertically intergradational, ancl clolornitic

itabirite occurs also within the clolomites of the Gandarela Fo¡mation (Dorr lI, 1969). So, it
scems more probable thal the dolomitic itabirite tepresents a carbonatic facies of the Cauê
Formation modified by a clolomitization process which occur¡ed during cliagenesis, instoad of a

product of carbonate-rich r¡ineralization of the quartz itabirite. The marine origin of the
dolomitic itabirite is also indicated by the C ancl O isotopes of clolomite, which present ôr3C

varying from -2.5%opoø to -0.8%o non (average of -1.7%"), while the oxygen isotope data
clisplays ôr80 values varying ftom -12.4o/oo p53 to *8.5%op¡rs (average of -10.5%o). These values

conelate well witli those of the stromatolitic carbonates of the Gandarela Formation of the Minas

basin (Sial et al. 2000) and also with calbonates of the Wittenoom Formation of the Hamersley

basin (Veizer et al. 1990). Isotope clata of the dolomitic itabirite are quite different f¡om those

found in catbonates of the dolomitised jaspilite of the N4 mine in Carajás and in hypogene

caÍbonates of the North Deposit in Tom Price (Table 6). Depleted ôr3C values of hypogene

carbonates from these mines comparecl with the values of dolomite of the dolomitic iiabirite are

additional evidence that this rock was not formed by hydrotermalism of the quartz itâbirite.
