Anothel issue in the hypogene-supergene moclels of Beukes et al, (2002) ancl Dalstra and

Guedes (2004) regarcls the protore of the soft high-grade ores. According to the authors, the soft

high-grade ore could not have been fonned only from quartz itabirite. Still, thousands of meters

of drill cores from the Tamancluá mine ancl other mines of the region, such as the Capitdo do

Mato, Pico ancl Sapecado (Fig. l), rnany of tliem in fiesh itabirites, intelcept only quartz itabirite.

Carbonate-rich altered itabirites have never been founcl in deepest levels below the water table in

these mines. Then, it is highly reasonable to assume that the soft high-grade otrcs at those mines

originatcd from the quartz itabirite.

Despite the contentiorrs about the origin of the dolomitic itabilite, it is unquestionable
that the original cornposition of the itabiritic protore had a major role in the genesis ofhigh- and

low-grade soft ores in the QF, the clolomític itabirite beirÌg the more favorable to form high-

gratle tlcposits due to the higher solubility of dolomitc in relation to quartz. In fact, although the

majority of the iron ore reserves in the QF come from qìiartz itabirite protore, the richest
oreboclies come fi'om dolornitic itabirite. This is clcarly velificcl in thc Aguas Claras ancl Capào

Xavier mines, where the high-gracle or€s were formed only from the clolomitic itabirite. As to the

nature of the mineralizing fluid, Viel et al. (1987) suggested that it was meteoric water enrichecl

in CO2 originated from the decomposition of the superficial vegetation that would have leachecl

dolomite. I{ematite was not affectecl by meteoric solutions (Don II 1965; Eichler 1968),
remaining resiclually enrichecl. Viel et al. (1987) also suggest that, depending on the Eh and pH

of the solution, any ferlous iron present in tlolomite would be oxidized and precipitated. The

weathering prooess wâs highly enhanced by the marked bedding at high angle to the grouncl

surface shown by the BIFs in the Águas Claras mine, thus allowing a deep penetration of

weathering fluicls, abunclant in humi<l tropical climates, especially along fault an<l fracture
planes.

Our petrographic ancl geochemical data fit well \'/ith the moclel proposed by Viel et al.

(1997). They sliow that the dissolution of the the dolomitic bands of the itabirite generates a

highly porous material made of hematite and a brownish resiclue. Petrographic ancl Mössbauer

analyses indicate that hematite was not affected by the metcoric solutions. Thus, this brownish

residue comes from the dolomite clissolution. The clolomite composition is quite constant

throughout the whole sequence of dolomitic itabirite at the Águas Claras mine, with average Fe

antl Mn contents around 1.5%. SEM and TEM analyses revealed the presence of iron and

manganese oxicìes within the brownish residue, while MS intlicate fenihydrite in its
mineralogical composition. These observations lecl to the conclusion that the dissolution of



212

dolomite during weathering producecl solutions camying Mnz' and Fe2*, accortling to the
following reaction:

(Ca,Mg, Fe, Mn)(Co), -r 2lIzCOt ---, Cl' + Mg2' + Fe2' + Mn2'.r- 4I{Co3-
Calcium and magnesium were leached out from the weatl,ering profile , \¡ihile iron and
manganese precipitated along pores and fracture planes forming Mn-oxities ancl fenihydrite.

'I'he supergene alteration begins along fractures close to the surface and spreacls laterally

ancl do\¡r'nward from these zones. At the botlom contact zone of the soft ore with the dolomitic
itabirite, the weathering solutions are mote saturated in Ca and Mg and are, consequently, less

t'eactive, favoring the concentration of less soluble minerals, such as apatite. The intedìngcring

contact observed in this zone re{lects the clevelopment of the weathering front downwards, along

the most favorable, fracturecl zones, forming the pinnacles and preserving remnants of the
dolomitic itabirite.

Kink-bancls and slang folds in the soft ore associated with a Tertiary basin situated in the

central ancl cleeper part of the Águas Claras orebody also suggest that the soft ore resultecl from

the leaching of clolomite by supergene solutiol.rs. The removal of large quantities of dolomite

created large pore space volumes in the soft ore, which collapsed, forming kink-bancls and slang

folds, according to the rnoclel described by Ribeiro (2003) and Ribeiro and Carvalho (2002) for

tlte soft itabirite of the Pico mine. This process produced depressions in the central par1 of the

orebody, which were filled by sedimelìts of Tertiary age, accordiug to palynological studies of
Lima ancl Salalcl-Chebolclaeff (1981) ancl Maizatto (2001). 40Ar/3eAr datìng of supergene Mn-

oxides hostecl within the soft iron ore of the Sapecado mine camiecl out by Spier et al. (2005b)

suggests that most of the soft ore in the QF was formed cluring a major, intense, chemical

weathering periocl, around 5l -41 Ma.

An aclclitional evidence to suppott oü hypothesis comes from the prosence of poorly
crystalline f'errihyclrite within the porous bancls of the soft ote. This mineral is widespread in
sutface environments and, unless stabilized in some way, is transformed into more stable
goethite or hematite. Ferrihydrite can be proclucecl from Fellsolutions by fast oxiclation followecl

by hyclrolysis in pH<5. The rate of oxìdation govems the formation of goethite (slow oxiilation)

or ferrihydrite (fast oxidation). Due to its metastable nature, ferrihydrite can only be expected to

be founcl in environments where its hansformation into more stable oxides is inhibitecl or
retardecl (Cornell and Schwertmann 1996). According to Comell (1988), the presence of
lransition elements such as Mn can stabilize ferrihydrite. The close association of Mn-oxides
with fenihydrite in the residue of the dolomite clissolution ooulcl, therefor.e, have been



213

responsible for inhibiting the transformation of ferrihydrite into hematile or goethite.
Ferihydrite transfo¡ms into hematite at temperatures as low as 4'C, and the higher the
temperature, the higher the formation of hematite (Schwertrnann et al. 1985). Thus, if the soft ore

hacl been produced by the leaching of dolomite by hypogene solutions, ferrihyclrite woulcl not be

cxpected to be found.

Another important feature shown by the soft ore is the REEY clistribution pattern, very

similar to that of the clolomitic itabirite (Fig. 14c). Even when the massive and porous bancls of

the soft ore are considered separately, lhe REEY patlern is the same, as shown in Figs. l4b and

d. Figure l4c1 ancl Table 3 show that REEY are concentratecl in the dolomitic bands of the

protore. The leaching of clolomite promoted the REEY enrichment in the porous bancls of the

soft orc ancl dcpletion in the massivc bancls, but the original trend was preserved. This can be

explained by taking into accorurt that REEY in the dolomitic bands of the dolomitic itabirite are

associatecl mainly with the clastic contamination of these predominantly chemical sediments
(Spier et al. 2005a). f)epletion in REEY in the massive bancls of the soft 01e in relation to the

iron-rich bands of the protore (Fig. l4cl) indicates that the REEY were mostly in dolomite which

was leached away during weathering.

In summary, many features observed in thc soft high-grade ore of the Águas Claras mine,

such as: (1) gradual transition from the dolomitic itabirite into the soft ore; (2) clisappearance of

the soft ore clown dip, leaving pinnacles fomecl by dolomitic itabirite; (3) pockets of dolomitic

itabirite witlìin the soft ore; (4) occurrence of slump folds in the soft ore, and Tertiary basins

locally blanketing the orebody; (6) petrogmphic evidences of clolomite clissolution forming Mn-

oxides and ferrihydrite, and (7) a similar REEY pattern for the dolomitic itabirite and the soft ore

indicate that soft high-gracle ore in the Águas Claras mine was formed by leaching of clolomite

from the clolomitic itabirite by meteoric vr'ater.

The occutrence of bauxite cleposits formed from Tertiary kaolinitic sediments locally

blanketing the high- and low-grade ores of the Capão Xavier mine is a strong evidence that the

chemical weathering in the region was intense. Il was enough to leach dolomite from the
clolomitic itabirite of the Ágr.ras Claras ancl Capão Xavier mines, but was not ablc to form largc

volumes of soft high-gra<le ores froln quartz itabirite in either mine. On the othe¡ hand, at the

Tamanthrá mine, quartz itabirite was the protore of the huge soft high-grade orebody. It is
unlikely that the soft ore could have been formed by meteoric leaching ftom quartz itabirite in

this mine, unless another structural control, such as metavolcanic or mafic dykes, acting as

impermeable barlicrs, had played an important role. This hypothesis neecls to be considcred, but



214

tliere are rnany field relationships previously mentionecl ilr [he tex[ which favor the genesis of

soft ores in the Tamanduá mine by hypogene solutions.

CONCLUSIONS

The detailed minel'alogical and geoûhemical study of the soft and hard high-gracle ores rn

the Águas Claras nine showed â very simple mineralogical and chemical composition. Both ores

consist essentially of hematite, occuuing as martite, anhedral to glanula/tabular hcmatite and,

locally specularite- Hematite is very pure ancl well crystallizecl. It occurs growing over martite

crystals or as individual crystals. Gangue minerals are vely rare, corlsisting of dolomite, sericite,

chlorite and apatite in the hard and soft ores, and Mn-oxicìes and fenihyclrite in the soft ore,

where they ale concentrated within the porous bands. Flard and soft oles consist almost ontirely

of Fe2O3, with higher amount of detrimental impurilies, especially MnO, in the soft ore. Botl.r

hard and soft ores are very low in h'ace elements. The soft ore preserves the REEY pattem of the

dolomitic itabirite, suggesting that weathering promoted a residual enrichment in REEY, without

fractionation.

Field relationships, petrological and geochemical data indicate that the high-grade ores at

the Águas Claras mine have a clual origin, involving hypogene and supergene processes. The

occurrence of the hard massive high-grade ore within fresh dolomitic itabirite is a good evidence

of its hypogene origin. Microstructures and granoblastic fabric of the harcl ore inclicate that its

genesis occurrecl prior to or concomitant with the main cleformational event that affected the

tocks at the \ryestern side of the QF, tìuring the Transamazonian orogeny (2.1-2.0 Ga).
Mineralogical and geochemical data provided little inforrnatiou tegarcling lhe hypogene solutions

ancl their precipitates at the Águas Claras mine. Further investigations on the detailecl stnrctural

contlol of the hard high-grade orebodies, oombinecl with rnicrothermometio investigations, are

necessary to determine the lole of hyclrothennal fluids in the folmation of the haral high-grade

ores at the QF.

Otherwise, despite the arguments about the origin of the clolomitic itablrite, the fielcl

relationships, mineralogical and geochemical clata strongly indicate the supergene origin of the

soft high-grade ore of the Águas Claras mine. Weathering of the dolomitic itabirite leachecl

dolomite, leaving a highly porous, saprolitic ole, consisting almost entirely of hematite with very

suborclinated gangue minerals. Among these are Mn-oxides antl ferrihyclrite, precipitated along



215

pores and fractures planes of the ore from solutions carrying Mnz* and Fe2' liberated cluring

dolomite clissolution. The occurrence of feruidydrite in the soft ore is a good evidence of its

supergenÇ origin. Dala from palynological studies caried out in secliments ofbasius that blanket

sorne high-gracle cleposits in the QF, associatecl with 
40Ar/reAr 

clating of supergene Mn-oxicles

hostecl within the soft iron ore of the Sapecatlo mine, suggest that most of the soft ore in the QF

was formed during a major, intense, chemical weatheritrg period, around 5l-41 Ma.

The original composition of fhe itabiritic protore has a major role in the genesis of high-

ancl low-gracle sofì ores in the QF. Under the same weathering antl structural conditions, the

clolomitic itabirite is more favorable to form high-gracle deposits than quartz itabirite, due to the

higher solubility of dolomite in relation to quLairtz. Field relationships at the Águas Claras and

Capão Xavier deposits suggest that it is not possible to form huge sof't high-grade cleposits from

quârtz itabitite, rurless another control, such as impermeable baniers, hacl played an important

role.

The occumence of huge tonnage of soft ore hostecl in quartz itabirite in the Tamadrlá

deposit, and the close association between haril, medium and soft ores, suggest that all those ores

were mostly formed cluring the hypogene process that generated the harcl ore, representing

different stages of the hypogene alteration. If this hypothesis is correct, the prcsence of a
carbonate-rich protore is not a necessary condition to the genesis of large high-grade oreboclies,

as sirggested by Beukes et al. (2002) ancl by Dalstra ancl Guedes (2004).

Though rnany issues remain to be clarified, we believe that the hypogene-supergene

modified genetic model is the best onc to explain the origin ofthe high-grade ores at the QF. The

diversity of geological and structural contexts where the ore occr.rrs sr.rggests the local
preponclerancy ofhypogene ol supergene p[ocesses in each particular orebocly.

EVOLUTION OF LATERITIC IRON DEPOSITS IN THE
eu¡.untlÁTnRo rnRRÍrBRo, MINAS GERAIS, BRAZTL

Weathering profiles overlying the Sapecaclo, Pico ancl Andaime iron ore deposits,

Quadrilátero Ferrífero (QF), Minas Gerais, Brazil, reach depths of 150-400 m ancl host worlcl-

class supergene iron oreboclies. In adclition to hematite, goethite, ancl some relic quartz, the

deeply weathered itabirites (metamorphosecl banded iron formation) contain supergene
cllptomelane, hollandite, ancl pyrolusite. These manganese oxicles are preferentially
concenûated at the contact between weathered Cauô Formation itabirites and adjacent dolomites

of the Gandarela Formation, and their clistribution provirlcs information on the propagation of the

weathering front as the supergene ore boclies formed.

Laser incremental-heating ooAr/toA. results for 69 grains extractecl fiom 23 samples

collected at depths ranging from 5 to 150 m reveal ages ranging fromca.62 to 14 Ma. Older Mn-

oxides occur near the surface, while younger Mn-oxides occur at depth. However, many

samples collected at the weathering-bedrock interface yield ages in the 5l-41 Ma range,
suggesting that the weathering profiles in the Quadrilátero Feffífero had already reached their

present depth in the Paleogene. The age velsus depth clistribution obtained in this study suggests

that little further advance of the weathering front has occurred in the Quadrilátero Fenífero

lateritic profiles during the Neogene.

INTRODUCTION

The Quaclrilátero Ferrífero (literally, the Iron Quaclrangle), Minas Gerais (Fig. l), hosts

one of the largest concentrations of lateritic iron orc deposits on Ealth, It also hosts lhe most

complete and well-developecl weathering profiles in southeastern Brazil, reaching depths of400

- 500 m, ancl averagiug 150 m. These weathering profiles are cleveloped on Paleoproterozoic
Minas Supergroup rocks which outcrop along plateaus ancl riclges with heights ranging frorn

1.100 to 2.100 m elevation, sr.rrror¡nded by clissected areas, where Archean granite-gneiss

basement units and the Rio das Velhas Gleenstone Belt ale exposed (Fig. 2).

implications because of the extreme depths and antìquity of weatheling processes reoordecl in

these plofrles (Carmo and Vasconcelos, 2004; Calmo antl Vasconcelos, 2003; Dorr ll, 1969;
King, 1956). Despite their imporlance, several questions regarc'ling the geriesis ofQF weathering

profiles remain unansweled: How did they fonn? How long did it tâke? When did it start? Uncler

what climatic conditions clid these weathering profiles evolve? Why are they preserved? Are they

still forming loday? Answers to these questions have many implications to our unclerstanding of

surficial processes in general ancì in quantifuing the genesis of supergene ore deposits in

manganifcl'ous itabirites at the Sapecailo ancl Anclaime MBR mines (Figs. l-2), provicle suitable

samples for ooA./tuA. dating. a0Ar/3eAr geochronology pennits clating of K-bearing manganese

oxides forrnecl at different depths in the weathering profiles ancl therein allows to measure the

rate of propagatiorì of the weathering front and the timing of formation of the profiles
(Vasconcelos, 1999a; Vasconcelos et al., 1994b).

The laser incremental-heating a0Ar/3eAr methocl has been used to date supergene
hollandite-group miuelals from weathering profiles across the world (Dammer et al., 1996;

Dammer et al., 1999; Hénocque et al., 1998b; Li and Vasconcelos, 2002; Ruffet et al., 1996b;

Vasconcelos, 1992; Vasconcelos et a1., 1992; Vasconcclos et al., 1994a) provicling a usefi.rl tool

in the stucly of weathering processes. Hollanclite-group Mn-oxides are suitable to aoAr'/3eAr

dating due to their relatively high K contents (l-5 wT%) and their K ancl a0Ar retentivity. These

hollandite-group minerals generally form clusters of oriented crystallites (10-20 pm long and l-2

¡rm wide) (Vascor,celos et aI., 1994c). These clusters have a large volume of intercrystalline

space that may absorb ancl aclsorb large quantities of atmospheric aoAr (Vasooncelos et al., 1995).

On the other hand, hollandite{ype crystallites form tunnel structures lhât fâvors rhe
imprisonment of large cations like K, Ba, and Pb. These tunnel sites quantitatively tetain a0Ar

procluced by ooK ilecay (Vasconcelos et al., 1995). Incremental+eating analyses of Mn-oxicle

clustets liberate atmospheric argon adsorbed or happed in intercrystalline or damaged
intracrystalline sites at low temperature heating steps; radiogenic 40Ar* ancl nucleogenic 3eAr

hosted in the intracrystalline tunrrel sites are only libe¡ated at higher temperatures steps. The

âbility to tap each argon reservoir separately permits determining accrrate ancl precise ages for

these minerals, in acldition to retrieving useful information on a sample's Ar ancl K retentivity,

the physical properties of the sites where these elements occur, the possible preseuce of
contaminants, and any significant 3eAr recoil losses the mineral may undergo<luring inadiation

(Vasconcelos, 1999b).

We will present below the results of aoAr/3eAr clating of 69 grains extracted flom 23
samples of Mn-oxides distributed from -5 m to -150 rn below the present surface in two distinct

QF weathering profiles. We will cliscuss the reliability of the results obtainecl in light of
informations obtainecl by petrographic observations ancl scanning electron microscopy (SEM), x-

ray diffractometry (XRD), and electron mictoprobe (EMP) analyses. We will finally discuss the

significance of the geochronological results to the formation of the weathering profiles in the QF

region, in particular, and the genesis of the supergene iron ore boclies, in general.



GEOT,OGICAL SETTfNG

Regional Geology

The geology and the lithoshatigraphy of the QF were described in detail by the USGS-

DNPM team between 1946 ancl 1963, ancl snmmarizecl by Doru II (1969)- Since then, the subject

has been reviewed by several authors (Alkmim and Marshak, 1998; Chemale Jr. et al., 1994;

Ladeira and Viveiros, 1984; Marshak and Alkmim, 1989; Renger et al., 1994). The most
important lithostlatigraphic units of the Quaclrilátero F'errífero (Fig. l) are Archean to
Paleoproterozoic granitic-gneissic basemcnt, Archean greenstone belt sequences (Rio clas Velhas

Supergroup), the Paleoproterozoic Minas Supetgroup and post-Minas intrusive rocks.

The giant iron ore deposits of the Quaclrilátero Ferrífero are hosted in itabirites of the

Minas Supergroup, which consist of three Paleoproterozoic sequences (Babinski et al., 'l995;
Nocc, 1995; Renger et al., 1994). The lowest unit is the Calaça Group, which consists of alluvial

conglomerates and sanclstones grading upwards into shallow-water marine siltstones ancl

mudstones, The intermecliate ltabira Group consists mainly of chemical sedimentary rocks. A

metamorphosed bandecl iron formation (itabirite) unit of variable composition occurs at the base

of the Itabira Group ancl, together with hematitic ancl dolomitic phyllites, marbles and dolomites,

constitutes the Cauê Formation. The original stratigraphic thickness of the iron formation may

have been in the order of250-300 m, but it now ranges in apparent thickness from a few meters

to more than 1,400 m, owing to tectonic rock flowage (Dorr II, 1964). The Car¡ê Formation
grailes npward into dolomites and dolomitic/manganiferous itabirites of lhe 2.4 Ga Gandarela

Formation (Babinski et a1., 1995). Clastic sediments (with subordinate dolomites) of the
Piracicaba Group overlie the ltabira Group. The uppermost sequence of the Minas Supergroup is

the Sabará Group, a sequence of metamorphosed volcanoclastic sediments, turbiclites, BIFs
(bancled iron formations), and conglomerates (Renger et a,L, 1994) clated âs Transamazonian (2.1

- 1.7 Ga.).
Deep \¡/eathering of the ltabira Group BIFs, postulated to have occurred cluring the

Mesocenozoic, ploducecl the large supergene iron orebodies spread throughout the QF (Dorr,

1969). A tolal of 29 Gtons of iron ore, rnined continuously since the beginning of the 40's ancl

having prodrlced more than 3 Gtons of high-graile iron ore, âre estimated to occur in the region

(TEX Report, 2002; W alde, 1986; Wallace, 1965). Total production in 2000 in the QF region

was I 15 Mtons and is estimateci for 2004 at 160 Mtons (TEX Report, 2002). Most of the cleep

weathering profiles in the legion are complete stratified weathering profiles, exhibiting an

234



235

indurated cap (cariga) ovetlying absolute and relative enrichecl supetgene iron ores, which

imrnediatcly overlie saplolit ic horizons.

Geomorphologically, the Quadlilátero Ferrífero (literally the iron quadrangle) consists of

a ronghly square 7000 km2 tegion (Fig. 2a) characterized by variotts plateaus, ranging in height

from 1100 to 2100 m elevation, sur¡ounded by dissected plains at ca. 500-600 m elevation. The

quadrangle is delimited by steeply dipping BIFs ancl quartzites that constitute elevated ancl

highly resistant barriers to erosion ancl scarp retr€at driven by the creeks ancl streams dtaining

into the plateau. The western limit of the QF is the Serra da Moecla, its northern limit the Ser¡a

do Cuffal, the eastcl'n limit the Serra do Caraça, ancl the southern limit the Sena clo Ouro Branco

(Figs. I and 2). The oore of the Quadrangle is drained by the north-flowing Rio cìas Velhas,
creating a tlissectecl winclow into the Archean Bação Complex (Fig. 2a). This inner depression is

surrouncled by several tleeply weathered plateaus developed on BlFs ancl quartzites. The eastern

section of the QF hosts a 700 km2 plateau, the Moeda Syncline, clelimited by the Serras da

Moeda (W), Sena do Curral (N), Serra clas Serrinhas (E), and Serra do Otro Branco (S) (Fig.

2a). This plateau hosts several important supergene ore boclies, included the Sapecado and

Andaime deposits, located in the Sena das Serrinhas, investigatetl in this study (Fig.2b).

Weathering profilcs along the Sema da Moeda were investigated in an associated study (Cauno

and Vasconcelos, 2003).

The QF plateaus have been interpreted as remnants of an ancient erosion surface

developed before the Africa-South America break-up (the Gondwana Surface of King (1956)).

Weathering profìles on the plateaus are consistently deeper (up to 400 m) and more<leveloped

than weathering profiles on sunounding plains and dissected valleys (<100 m). Landsurfaces on

the plateaus are also distinct fi'om the surrouncling plains because they are blanketed by strongly

iron-hydroxicle cemented covers (cangas), whioh impart a smooth chatacter to the plateau

lanclsurfaces. When the cangas are breached by recent erosion, they form shatp scatps (Fig. 2c),

another distinctive characteristic of this landscape. F'inally, internal basins on the plateaus (e.g.,

Bacias do Fonseca and Gandarela), fillecl with argillite, lignite, sandstone, diamictite, and

kaolinitic sediments now partially weatherecl to bauxite, are associatecl with collapse structures

(karstic lakes) formed during weathering of unclerlying banded iron formations (Ribeiro, 2003)

or with extensional tectonic activity during the Paleogene (Maizatto, 2001; SantAnna et al.,

1997). We chose to study the weathering history of two supergene iron ore deposits in the

Moecla Syncline because of the likelihoocl that these supergene systems host the most complete

information about the weathering history of the Quadrilátero Ferrífero and of the hypothesized



236

Gondwana lanclsurface of King (1956). We also chose to study these profiles becanse the

intimate lelationship between supergene iron ore anci datable supergene Mn-oxi<les pelmits

relating the timing of Mn-oxide precipitation with the evohrtion of the chemical reactions leadrng

to thc formation ofsupcrgcne en¡ichecl iron orebodies in the legion.

Local Geology

Three adjacent iron mines (Sapecado, Pico, and Andaime), locatcd along the Sena das

Serrinhas on the eastern margin of the Moeda Syncline (F'igs. l-2), provicle access to deeply

weatherecl ancl supergene enriched BIFs. Weathcring profiles at these mines vary frorn a few

meters to ca. 200 m below the present surface (Fig. 3a-c). This large variation in weatliering

profile depth results on an interlayering of unweatherecl itabiritcs with cleeply weathere<l

itabirites and softìematite ores. Spier et al. (2003) ptovides detailed charâcterizatious of the iron

ores and their hosts rocks in these cleposits. In this study, we dated samples from the Sapecado

and Andaime weathering profiles, briefly desoribed below.

The Sapecaclo orebocly represents the southem extension of the Pico orebody. It is
composed of lenses ofunindurated and induratecl iron orss interlayered with relatively weathered

quartz itabirite. The geological resources of the Sapecado orebody are of 400 Mtons (MBR,

internal report). The major geological units present at the Sapecado mine are itabirites and iron

ores of the Cauê Formation, clastic metasedimentary rocks of thc Moecla and Batatal Formations,

and predominantly chemical metasedirnentary rocks of the Gandarela Formation (Fig. 3b-c). The

rocks are oriented along a general strike N30"-35'E, rlipping 45"-90' to SE or NW. The

quartzites ofthe Moeda Formation crop out continuously along the eastern edge of the mine and

show a vcry consistent sub-vefiical dip ancl, in general, weakly developecl foliation. The
qr.lartzites exhibit abrupt contaots '¡r'ith the overlying phyllites of [he Batatal Formation. The

uppermost Gandarela Formation crops out at the pit's westem wall. It consists of dolomitic
phyllite and<leeply weathered dolomite with a gratlual contact r¡/ith the itabirites. The main

banciecl itou fo nation at the Sâpecado mine is the quartz itabirite, the protore of the iron ore
bodies. Thìs quartz itabirite is a typical metarnorphosed BIF and consists ofalteurate microbands

of quartz with martite and hematite. Total or partiâl leaching of qrartz during weatherìng
promoted the residual enrichment of iron, generating the soft iron ores (Spier et a1., 2003). Soft

ores are highly porous and consist of microbands of aggregates of martite ancl hematite still

cementecl together with highly porous bancls where martite and hematite grains fìll

The Andaime orebody is located l0 km North of the Pico mine (Fig. l), representing the

northern continuity of the iron mineralization. The rocks of the Minas Supergroup at this region

are oriented along shike Nl0'-30'W, dipping 40o-80o to NE. The exploration of the Andaime

orebody started in 2004 and its geological resources, still under evaluation, are ca. 100 Mtons

(MBR, intemal report). The orebody consists of soft quartz itabirite which occurs within the

weathering profile, along the strike of the siliceous banded iron formation. Lenses of
manganiferous iøbirite are interlayered with the iron ore.

Manganiferous itabirite is a particular type of soft iron ore that generally occurs at the top

of the Cauê Formation, at the contact with the Gandarela Formation (Fig. 3a-b) in all three -
Pico, Sapecado, and Andaime - mines. It consists of irregularly distributed lenses varying from
decimeters to 20 m width, 5 - 100 m length, with depths varying from a few meters to 150 m.
The lenses occur parallel to the itabirite units, interbedded with them (Figs. 3a-b and 4a). The

manganiferous itabirite contains on average 48 wtYo (ll wt% -63 wt%) Fe and 6 wto/o (3 wP/o -
14 wt%) Mn. Rarely the Mn content exceeds 15 wt%.In this case, the ore is called Fe-Mn ore.

Manganese oxides in the manganiferous itabirite are irregularly distributed. They generally

cement the walls of pores in the soft iron ores or form cm-size botryoidal bands precipitated in

cavities and cracks (Fig. ab).

The Pico, Andaime, ancl Sapecado orebo<lies are capped by small basins fillecl with

argillites and siltstones. These type of basins, associated with karstic depressions created by lhe

collapse of the BIF after leaching of silica ancl carbonate minerals duling weatheling (Ribeilo,

2003; Ribeiro ancl Carvalho, 2002), wete dated as Paleocene to Eocene based on pollen

assemblages (Lima and Salard-Cheboldaeff, I 98 I ; Maizatto, 200 1).

SAMPLING AND ANALYTICAL PROCEDURE

The visual iclentification of black Mn-oxides dispersed throughout dark hematite ores is a

major challenge. To overcome this sampling difficulty, we focused our search for datable

supergene Mn-oxides on clrill cores previously analyzed for Mn. Sections with high Mn contents,

where manganiferous itabirite ancl Fe-Mn ore occrr, were caref'ully examinecl with a hand lens

ancl any suitable occunence of datable Mn-oxide sampled. Datable Mn-oxides, hollandite-group

minerals, are easily recognizable based on their superior hardness (> 6), a steel-blue metallic

luster, and a botryoidal texturc. Section 6300E of the Sapecado mine was chosen for detailed

sampling clue to the presence of a prominent manganiferous itabirite unit, which forms a

continuous lens from the surface tlown to -150 m (Fig. 3b). We sampled each meter of

manganiferous itabirite that contained suitable Mn-oxide minerals. The samples selected are

supposed to represent a time-stratigraphic sequence from the oldest samples at the near sudace

envjronment to the youngest sample at the base of the weathering profile (fresh rock-weathering

interface).

Complementary sampling at Sections 4700E ancl 3500E, at the Sapecado ancl Andaime

mines, respectively (Figs. 2-3), provicle information on weathering age variation along strike. At

Section 4700E (Sapecado), we sampled Mn-minsrals that occLr along fiacture planes of deeply

weathered dolomites of the Gandarela Formation (Fig. 3c); at Section 35008 (Anclaime), we

sample<l manganiferous itabirite (Fig. 3a).

Sample preparation followed the method cletailecl by Vasconcelos (1999b) ancl
Vasconcelos et al, (2002). Samples were crushed to 0.5 - 2 mm, ultrasonically cleanecl in
distillecl water and absolute ethanol, and clriecl uncler a heat lamp. The clean sample fragments

were examined under a binocula¡ microscope, and six to eight visually homogeneous graìns were

hand-picked and loacled into aluminum disks for neutron ilradiation. The samples were inadiated

for 14 hours, along with the Fish Canyon Sanidine stanclard (28.02 ! 0.28 Ma), in the Triga
reactor at the B-l CLICIT Facility, Radiation Centre, Oregon State University Reactor, Oregon,

USA. After a cooliug-off perjotl of three wecks, three grains from each sample were loadecl into

a 145-pit copper disk, baked at 180 "C fot l3 hours, and incrementally hcatod by a continuons l0

W Ar-ion laser with a defooused beam al the UQ-AGES laboratory, Australia. Gases releasecì

during incremental-heating were cleanecl by a cryocooled trap (T: -130 "C) and two C-50 SAES
Zr-V-Fe getter purnps, and the clean gas fraction expancled into a MAP-215-50 mass
spectrometer. Air pipettes and blanks were run before and after each sample to conect for
backgrouncl and mass cliscrimination. Air pípettes, blanks, ancl unknowns were analyzed by thc
peak hoping method, 8-10 cycles were measured for each isotope, ancl 7 measurements of a0Ar,

RESULTS AND DISCUSSION

Mincralogy and Petrography

ReflecteclJight microscopy and SEM investigation show that cryptomelane, pyrolusite

ancl hollandite are the main Mn-oxides present. These minerals occur cementing pore spaces in

tlie iron ore or form mm-size growth bands (Fig. 5a-d). Minor Al-enrichment generally occurs at

tlle contact between Mn-oxides ancl the hosting iron ore. Pure lithiophorite was not detectecl in

any of the grains analyzecl. Most Mn-oxiiles are minemlogically complex (Fig. scl-g). l{ematite

(either as martite or tabular hernatite) inclusions âre commolr within Mn-oxicle grains,
particularly at tho contact of void-filling concletions wjth the iron ore (Fig. 5a). Goethite and

gibbsite bands alternate with Mn-oxides in some botryoiclal samples (Fig. 5h).

Manganese oxide textures are also variable. When cementing pores in the iron ore,

hollandite-group Mn-oxi<les are generally very pure, cryptocrystalline, and characterized by

botryoidal textul'es composed of micromeüic growth bands (Fig. 5b-d). Indiviclual microbands

display uniform grain size and mineralogical composition. Cryptomelane crystals iu microbands

occur as l0-20 micron neecllelike crystals, with l0:l aspect ratio, and oriented perpenclicularly
to the growth bands (Fig. 5e). When pyrolusite is present, coarse aggregâtes of 0.01 - 0.20 rnm
grains occur. Pyrolusite may also occur as radiating prismatic crystals aligned perpendicularly to

the growth bands, and it is often partially teplaced by hollandite-group phases (Fig. 5f-g).
Desiccation cracks are often observed in pyrolusite crystals (Fig. 5f-g).

Textural relationships and mineralogy of the samples indicate that Mn-oxides were

<lirectly precipitatecl from weathering solutions. Palagenetic relations among Mn minerals were

diffrcult to assess. Generally, cryptomelane and hollandite are older than pyrolusite (Fig. 5c), but

this is not always the case. Multiple generations of Mn-oxides, indicatecl by banded and
colloform textures, systems of intersecting veinlets, and mutual replacements, are observed (Fig.

6a-h). The small size of the Mn-oxide growth bancls (less than 20 ¡rm in average) does not allow

f'or the selection of fragments from a single generation, ln addition, many grains selected fo¡

geochronology may contain minor supergene pyrolusite, goethite, or gibbsite inclusions. Some

grains also contain martite-hematite inclusìons, which may cause further cornplications cl.rring

dating (see discussion below). Petrographic and SEM examinations, however, clearly show the

absence ofany hypogene K silicate in the samples submitied to a0Ar/3eAr geochronology.

Manganese Oxide Paragen€sis

Fielcl ancl petrographic observations indicate that Mn-oxides samplecl in [his shrdy formed

cluring chemical weathering of the dolomite-bearing itabirite of the Cauê Formation ancl tho

clolomite of the Gandarcla Folmation. Manganese and iron are present as minor elements iri the

clolomite. Manganese ancl iron are also common in carbonate celnents associatecl with the

diagenetic or hyclrothermal alteration ofthe BIFs. Mn'2 ancl Fe'2 are released into the weathering

solutions during the dissolution of the Mn-bearing carbonates. As long as the \¡r'eather¡ng
solutions remain relatively reducing ancl neutral to acidic, Mn'2 stays in solution. If the Mn*2-

bearing solutions encourter clescending oxygenatecl mcteoric solutions along permeable horizons

and fault planes, Mn*2 readily oxidizes and precipitates as Mn*a-oxides ancl -hydroxicles

(pyrolusite, ramsclellite, manganite). Alternatively, when Mn*2-bearing weathering solutions

oncourÌter str-ongly alkaline conditions, which often occurs at the contact between the BIF and

the host carbonates of the Gandarela Formation, Mnt2 may also reaclily oxiclize and precipitate as

Mn*a oxides/hyclroxides. If, in addition to Mnu2, the weathering solutions also contain clissolved

K*1, Ba*2, or other cations, complex tunnel structure manganese oxides (romanéchile, hollandite,

cryptomelane, todorokite) may form. The processes above account for the common occurrence

of Mn-oxicles along faults and along the contact between the BIF and the adjacent carbonate

rocks. Manganese oxide paragenesis in the supergene iron orebodies suggests an intimate
association of the oxides with the weathering of the banded iron formations. This, in tu¡n,
âssures that geochronological analyses of the Mn-oxides provrcle information on the weathering

history of the BIFs.

Despite some of the complicating factors above, a very encouraging aspect of the lesults

[Iow old are the Quadrilátero FerrÍfero Weathering Proliles?

Well-defined and reproducible plateau ancl plateau-like ages, ranging lrom 61 .5 t 1.2 Ma
to 14.2 t 0.2 Ma (2o), inclicate a protracted history of chemìcal weathering for the Quaclrilátcro
Ferífero, which was alreacly ongoing in the Paleogcne ancl continued until the Neogene. The

ages obtained are compalible with ages obtainecl from another study of QF weathering profiles

(Carmo, 2004; Carmo ancl Vasooncclos, 2005). They are also in agreement with the palynologic

shrdies of the Gandarela and Fonseca basins carriecl out by Lima ancl Salarcl-Cheboldaeff (1981)

and by Maizatto (2001), which indicate that the seclimentation of thcse basins occurrecl during

the Midclle to Late Eocene. Considering that the genesis of the basins can be related to the

collapse structurcs formed iluling weathering of the unclerlying BIFs and rlolomites (Ribciro and

Carvalho, 2002), the geochronology results of the Sapecado and Anclaime mines, conoborated

by the palynologic rlata, indicate a prolongcd weathering history for the Quadrilátero Ferrífero,

alreacþ ongoing in the early Paleooene.

The absence of older geochronological lesults does not preclude a much older wcathering

history for the region. Older manganese oxides could exist and have not been sampled; older

manganese oxides could have been dissolved by more recent weathering events; or older

weathering assemblages could have been erocled from the upper parts of the profile cluring the

past 60 Ma. At this stage, based on the results presentecl in this study, we can only affirm that

the weathering profrles in the Quadrilátero Ferrífero are older than 6l .5t 1.2 Ma.

One noticeable featurc of the distribution of ages in the tbree weathering profiles

illustrated in Figure l0 is the similarity in age vs. depth obtained. Although older results are

obtainecl fi'om samples closer to the pfcsont sulfacc, while younger results occnr in cleeper

horizons in the profrle (Fig. lOa-b), several Mn-oxides sampled near the bedrock-weathering

interface yielcl ages at ca. 40 Ma (Fig. l0b-c). Youngel results (<30 Ma) occur in some cleep

horizons, br¡t the occlrrence of olcl manganese oxicles at the present weathering-bedrock
interface suggest that the Moeda Syncline weathering plofiles had alreacly reached their present

depth ca. 40 Ma, iudicating that very little advance of the weathering front has occurred in the

Neogene. Neogene ages founcl cleeper in the profrle may recorcl recrystallization of older Mn-

oxicles during more recent events, but they clo not require much aclvance ofthe weathering front

since ca. 40 Ma. Figure 12 illustrates the relationship between ages ancl elevations for the the

Moeda Syncline Mn-oxides.

Continuous or Episodic Weathering Record?

The presence of Paleogene sediments in karstic lakes overlying the Cauê ancl Gandarela

Formations, and the absence of other thick sedimentary units in the area, suggest that the QF

lithologies have been contiuuously exposed to surficial conditions sirlce the beginning of the

Tertiary. Icleograms for the weathering profrles at the Sapecaclo ancl Andaime mines, however,

<1o not yieltl a continuous clistribution of ages. In reality, the geochronological results strongly

cluster in the 50-40 Ma interual, with other prominent peaks at ca. 56 (Sapecado) and 32

(Anclaime) Ma. The lack of sruface samples from the Andaime profile may explain the absence

of olcler lesults for that profile. Although it is not our intention to compare the icleograms, peak

by peak, it is important to notice that some of the signifioant intervals (e.g., 50-40 Ma) of
mânganese oxide precipitâtion in the Sapecaclo profiles are also represented in the Sena da

Moeda profiles shrclied by Carmo and Vasconcelos (2005) (Fig. I lb). All of the profiles do
show clustering of ages at specific time periods, independently of where in the profiles the

samples were collected, suggesting an episodic history of mineral precipitation. Given the

longevity and the depth of the profiles, the complex history of tnineral dissolution ancl
reprecipitation, and the large al'ea covered by this study, fulther studies, at different sites ancl

Paleoclimatic Implications

The distribution of lateritic weathering profiles lTas been usecl as a paleoclimatic indicator

(Crowley ancl North, l99l; Fmkes, 1979; Nahon, 1986). The authols consider the presence of
those profiles as indicative of warm temperatures with seasonal rains, favoring intense chemical

weathering ancl consequently the development ofcleep weathering profiles.

A major limitation in using weathering profrles as paleoclimatic inclicator is the absence

of reliable numerical ages. In addition, the few studies whele ages of profiles are reportecl

(Dammer et dl., 1996; Dammer et al., 1999; Ruffet et al., 1996a; Vasconcelos et al., 1994b)

suggest that latetitic profiles do not form instantly but record a protl'acted history of mineral

dissolution and reprecipitation lasting tens of millions of years. The present study confirms that

lateritic ptofiles reflect a protracted history of exposure. The ages of the minerals in the profiles

record times in the past more propitious to chemical weathering.

The majority of the supergene Mn-oxides samples analyzed precipìtated between 5l ancl
4l Ma, sr.rggesting hot and wet climatic conclitions at that time interval. Palynologic clata for the

Gandarela and Fonscca basins reveals the plesence of an exubelant ancl diversifiecl paleoflora in

the Eocene, indicative ofhot and wet envitonmental conditions (Maizatto, 2001). This period is

coincitlent with the major periocls of chemical weatherrng tegistered at the Carajás, Amazon

region, Brazil (Ruffet et al., 1996a; Vasconcelos et al., 1994b), in Australia (Dammer et al.,

1996; Dammer et a1., 1999) and in Burkina Faso, Africa (Hénocque et al., 1998b). This might

indicâte that the climatic conditions that favoretì intense chemical weathering in the Eocene had

a mote global character.

Landscape Evolution Implications

The deeply strati{ied weathering profiles in the Quarìrilátero Ferrífero record weathering

processes alreacly orrgoing at the Paleogene, and may suggest even more ancient weathering in

the region. The absence of deeply stratified weathering profiles in the adjacent dissected valleys

(Fig. 2a), and evidence suggesting that weathering profiles in these dissectecl parts of the

landscape are much younger than the pro{iles on the plateaus (Carmo and Vasconcelos, 2004)

corroborate previous suggestions that the landsurfaces blanketing the QF plateaus are much olcler

than the acljacent disscctcd landsudaces. The lanclsurface characterized by the QF plateaus have



260

been narnecl "Gondwana Surface" (King, 1956). A subsequent cycle of erosion (the "South

America cycle", King, 1956) would have partially eroded the Gondwana Surface, creating the

more clissecled landscape surrounding it. Our s[udy does not have the legional chalacter ueecled
to adtü'ess the oxistence or not of these postulated landsurfaces ancl erosional cycles. However,

the geochronological results obtainecl for the QF profiles suggest that profiles in the elevatecl

landscape associated with deeply weathered bandecl iron formations, quartzites, and karstic

paleolake sediments are clistinctly olcler than weathering profiles in the surrounded clissectecl

plains and valleys, consistent with the existence ofa more ancient landsurface blanketing the QF
plateaus.

Implications for the Supergene Enrichment of Banded Iron Formations

The geochlonological results in this stucþ petmit drawing three major conclusions:

. that the supergene enrichment blankefs that make the Quadrilátero Ferrífero such a
prolifìc iron-proclucing region were already forming at more than 60 Ma;

. that most of the supergene processes had already reachecl their present extent at ca. 40
Ma;

. ancl that weathering processes in the Neogene have contributed little to the fufther
advance of the weathering fronts in the supelgene orebodies.

In addition, we may safely conclude that giant supergene iron oreboclies are likely to be

found only in the high elevation plateaus (Gondwana Suface) that were exposecl to the more

intense ancl prolonged weathering history. Dissected plains and valleys surrounding the QF

plateaus are likely to host only incipient supergene blankets.

The fact lhat the supergene enrichment blankets likely reached their present depths at ca.

40 Ma suggest that weathering solutions percolating through the profile were ineffective at

promoting fuÍher advances of the weathering front once the profile reachecl a certain depth.

This diminished weathering capacity may be relate<l to diminishing leactivity of the weathering

solutions at depth (e.g., depletion in dissolved oxygen or saturation with dissolved species), or it

may reflect the horizontal, as opposed to the vertical, rnigration of the weathering solutions once

they reach certain depths. The horizontally migrating weathering solutions dewater at the sicles

of the cliffs (Serra cla Setrinha, Figs. I and 2) at the headwaters of local springs.



CONCLUSIONS

Deep weathering profiles developecl within Paleoptotet ozoic BIFs of the Cauô Folrnation

at the Quaclrilátero Ferrífeto host Mn-oxides suitable for 
ooAr/toAr 

clating. These Mn-oxicles are

concentratecl in supergene Fe-Mn ore ancl manganifelous itabirite at the contact with the

Gandarela Formation. They consist of minerals of the hollandite group (cryptomelane and

hollandite) antl pyrolusite formed by precipitation from complex (Mn-, Fe-, K-, ancl Ba-rich)

weathering solutions. Petrographic and SEM investigations reveal the presence of several
generations of Mn-oxit1es.

Laser-heating 'oAloAr data reveal ages ranging from 62 [o 14 Ma, inclicating a
prolongecl history of weathering at the Quadtilátero Ferrífeto, already ongoing at least in

Paleogene and continuecl until Neogene. The rnajority of Mn-oxides, however, precipitatecì from

51 - 4l Ma with a peak at 47 Ma. This period is coinciclent with lhe development of srnall basins
formed by the collapse of the underlying BIFs cluring intonse chemical weathering, as inclicatecl

by palynologic clata obtained in the sediments.

Samples collected near the present surface or near the contact with the weathering-

bedrock interface present similat ages, indicating that the main weathering process was

developed around 46 Ma ago. Further chemical weathering had limitecl effect on the weathering

of the BIFs, which means that giant supergene iron ore cleposits were completely formed at the

Paleogene.

The coinciclence of the major period of precipitation of the Mn-oxicles (and therefore of

intense chemical weathering) at the QF with major periocls of precipitation in the Brazilian

Amazon (Ruffet et al., 1996a; Vasconcelos et al., 1994b), Australia (Dammer et al., 1996;

Dammer et al., 1999) and westetn Aûica (Héuocque et al., 1998a; flénocque et al., 1998b)

suggests that climatic conditions which favored intense chernical weathering in the Eocene hacl a

more global character.
